headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just had a couple of questions regarding how pricing trends are coming out or playing out in the spring. I guess, in the winter, things were a little bit better than expected, getting bigger year-over-year increases. Was curious if you are -- I know it
componenttext: So just had a couple of questions regarding how pricing trends are coming out or playing out in the spring. I guess, in the winter, things were a little bit better than expected, getting bigger year-over-year increases. Was curious if you are -- I know it's only May 3rd, but is this spring, are you getting the year-over-year increase so for that you've been used to in the previous years?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you pricing continues to be strong. January, February, we are close to 10% above where we were last year. Going into March and April, we're still 6% to 7% above where we were last year, which for the spring is still pretty solid.
componenttext: I would tell you pricing continues to be strong. January, February, we are close to 10% above where we were last year. Going into March and April, we're still 6% to 7% above where we were last year, which for the spring is still pretty solid.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so obviously, that 7% in April is not a small number, but it is a little bit down from the January, February. Any particular reason your revenue systems or the results are lining up that way?
componenttext: Okay. And so obviously, that 7% in April is not a small number, but it is a little bit down from the January, February. Any particular reason your revenue systems or the results are lining up that way?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we pushed rate harder in January, February and we gave a little bit in occupancy. You see our year-over-year delta come in a little bit and now we're kind of easing off that and going a little bit more with occupancy.
componenttext: So we pushed rate harder in January, February and we gave a little bit in occupancy. You see our year-over-year delta come in a little bit and now we're kind of easing off that and going a little bit more with occupancy.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last question, obviously, your management system, your revenue management system has try to optimize revenue. We get that. But just curious if we could see a bit more move outs and less move ins this quarter? Any patterns for reasons why mo
componenttext: Okay. And just last question, obviously, your management system, your revenue management system has try to optimize revenue. We get that. But just curious if we could see a bit more move outs and less move ins this quarter? Any patterns for reasons why more people -- more people left or less have moved in that you can point that happened this quarter that might be unusual?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you part of it is the unusual comp from last year. Last year, you had a really odd thing of the northeast where you had some pretty severe weather, which had very few move outs and very few move ins. So I think part of it's year-over-yea
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you part of it is the unusual comp from last year. Last year, you had a really odd thing of the northeast where you had some pretty severe weather, which had very few move outs and very few move ins. So I think part of it's year-over-year. If you look at a bigger average, call it a 5- to 7-year average, we're right in line with the 5- to 7-year average in terms of move ins and move outs both.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from RJ Milligan of Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from RJ Milligan of Baird.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering who those buyers are for the really low cap rates and how much appetite you think there is out there from that competition?
componenttext: I was wondering who those buyers are for the really low cap rates and how much appetite you think there is out there from that competition?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: RJ, it's Spencer. There's a lot of appetite for self-storage. I think it's no secret that it's probably the best performing asset class year in and year out. We're seeing pronounced competition everywhere we turn from trade buyers and non-trade buyers. An
componenttext: RJ, it's Spencer. There's a lot of appetite for self-storage. I think it's no secret that it's probably the best performing asset class year in and year out. We're seeing pronounced competition everywhere we turn from trade buyers and non-trade buyers. And the only comment I would make is as we look at this, it's great to buy this asset class but once you've purchased it, somebody's go to operate it. This is operationally intensive and we think that that creates opportunity and we'll just have to see how things play out but there's a lot of money chasing these assets.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on CofO deals, can you talk about the sort of underwritten development yields that you are seeing maybe a year ago versus today and sort of where that middle ground is in terms of a cap rate where you guys are willing to buy those assets?
componenttext: Okay. And then on CofO deals, can you talk about the sort of underwritten development yields that you are seeing maybe a year ago versus today and sort of where that middle ground is in terms of a cap rate where you guys are willing to buy those assets?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're still looking at cap rates, we typically underwrite them at 150 to 200 basis points. I would tell you that they bid more on the 150 basis points range. Recently, we've said note some deals and we continue to see things come in the 7.5 to 8 yields o
componenttext: You're still looking at cap rates, we typically underwrite them at 150 to 200 basis points. I would tell you that they bid more on the 150 basis points range. Recently, we've said note some deals and we continue to see things come in the 7.5 to 8 yields once they're stabilized.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ryan Burke of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ryan Burke of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of assets, small dollar amount but it's relatively uncommon for you. What was the specific rationale between [indiscernible] selling those properties and can you give us an update on just your plans for further dispositions if any?
componenttext: Of assets, small dollar amount but it's relatively uncommon for you. What was the specific rationale between [indiscernible] selling those properties and can you give us an update on just your plans for further dispositions if any?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So from our perspective, we will continue to look at markets and whether it's markets that are difficult for us to operate in or whether they are markets that we feel maybe have reached their potential and/or they may have a need for CapEx to be put into
componenttext: So from our perspective, we will continue to look at markets and whether it's markets that are difficult for us to operate in or whether they are markets that we feel maybe have reached their potential and/or they may have a need for CapEx to be put into those, so those are markets we'll look to dispose of assets. Some of these were a little bit more rural and maybe not as core as we would hope for in terms of rent per square foot and the income and population demographics.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, as you know, we are trying to build a company and dispositions have not been something that we talked a lot about. But I think you can expect going forward that you will see us looking at the very bottom end of our portfolio and taking a really good
componenttext: Ryan, as you know, we are trying to build a company and dispositions have not been something that we talked a lot about. But I think you can expect going forward that you will see us looking at the very bottom end of our portfolio and taking a really good look at the economic performance as well as the physical characteristics of that particular bottom segment and rationalizing whether it should be on the portfolio, and I think you'll see some activity year in and year out at the bottom end. But it's not going to be a wholesale initiative on our part because we are trying to build, not dismantle.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Are you able to give us a feel for what percentage of the properties the bottom end defines?
componenttext: Sure. Are you able to give us a feel for what percentage of the properties the bottom end defines?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Separate question, just back to New York City development, I believe that all of the properties in your current pipeline in the NYC boroughs all right minority stakes. Is that -- do that speak to the desire to control your exposure there? Or is that more
componenttext: Separate question, just back to New York City development, I believe that all of the properties in your current pipeline in the NYC boroughs all right minority stakes. Is that -- do that speak to the desire to control your exposure there? Or is that more just the fact that that's the opportunity that has presented itself there?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a combination of the opportunity that's presented itself as well as our ability to leverage our returns in a lower cap rate environment.
componenttext: It's a combination of the opportunity that's presented itself as well as our ability to leverage our returns in a lower cap rate environment.

componenttext: Okay. And you picked up 1 property or JV interest in 1 property in the Bronx during the quarter. That was 42% occupied as of March 31. Do you happen to have what the occupancy was on that asset as of January 1?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that specifically in front of me, but it's one that's opened recently. It continues to lease up really well.
componenttext: I don't have that specifically in front of me, but it's one that's opened recently. It continues to lease up really well.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jonathan Hughes of Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jonathan Hughes of Raymond James.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had one, most of mine have been answered but what renewal rate increases were you able to pass on to tenants in this first quarter? And maybe how many left or vacated due to not wanting to pay those renewal rate bumps?
componenttext: Just had one, most of mine have been answered but what renewal rate increases were you able to pass on to tenants in this first quarter? And maybe how many left or vacated due to not wanting to pay those renewal rate bumps?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's take the second piece first, Jonathan. Our existing customer rate increase program continues to show financially that we are hitting the sweet spot. Yes, there might be a few move outs where people won't accept it but the economics are compelling in
componenttext: Let's take the second piece first, Jonathan. Our existing customer rate increase program continues to show financially that we are hitting the sweet spot. Yes, there might be a few move outs where people won't accept it but the economics are compelling in terms of the gain that we pick up from the high 90%, 95%, 98%, whatever it is that accept it and don't move out because this is a very sticky product type. Existing customer rate increases, it's in the 9% to 10% range quarter in, quarter out and it works well.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, are many not just leaving maybe because they simply don't want to take the time to move their stuff out? Or is it just lack of available space?
componenttext: And then, are many not just leaving maybe because they simply don't want to take the time to move their stuff out? Or is it just lack of available space?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's be realistic about this, Jonathan. If you're renting a unit and you get a rate increase letter that says your rent is going up $15, you are not likely to go get a U haul truck, take a Saturday morning, pack up your stuff, go down the street, on unpa
componenttext: Let's be realistic about this, Jonathan. If you're renting a unit and you get a rate increase letter that says your rent is going up $15, you are not likely to go get a U haul truck, take a Saturday morning, pack up your stuff, go down the street, on unpack your stuff, return haul truck to save it's $15. People just want go through the effort to do that. It's an incredibly sticky product. What we have found is a rate increase, more often than not, might finally signal to somebody, you know what, the problem I was trying to solve has passed. Maybe I should move out. And that is, as I said a very, very small percentage, single digits, low single digits of the total customer base. So existing customer rate increases. It's a great programming. We think we're operating in a sweet spot.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on discounts, what percentage of customers are receiving some type of promotion this quarter? And also, just wanted to get a sense of what your budgeting for discounts this spring leasing season? You're obviously coming off a higher occupancy level h
componenttext: Just on discounts, what percentage of customers are receiving some type of promotion this quarter? And also, just wanted to get a sense of what your budgeting for discounts this spring leasing season? You're obviously coming off a higher occupancy level having smoothed out some of the Q4 seasonal dip. Just want to get a sense of discounts.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, discounts during the first quarter, about 75% to 85% of our customers moving in, coming in or first time renters or new customers receive the discount. That is higher than it was last year. When we originally looked at the year, I think we had hopes
componenttext: Yes, discounts during the first quarter, about 75% to 85% of our customers moving in, coming in or first time renters or new customers receive the discount. That is higher than it was last year. When we originally looked at the year, I think we had hopes that discounts would be flat. Now we're projecting they will be up slightly. But if you think of it in terms of whether discounts are up or down, our rates are up 5% to 10%. So clearly, if you rent to the same number of people, discounts will be up 5% to 10% over where they were last year. We'd hope to be able to cut them and keep them flat as a percent, but now we're seeing that they will be up slightly and we're projecting the same into the spring leasing season, Todd.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And just one last question, I wanted to follow up on the question about the assets you sold already you're going to be managing on a third-party basis. Can you just go over maybe what the standard agreement you have in place is? Is it cancelabl
componenttext: All right. And just one last question, I wanted to follow up on the question about the assets you sold already you're going to be managing on a third-party basis. Can you just go over maybe what the standard agreement you have in place is? Is it cancelable by either side? The reason I ask is I usually get into the third-party management with the potential to buy the property, but I wanted to see if you can get out of this if you're obviously disposing of it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's pretty simple. It's a month-to-month contract. We do advance some money for the rebranding of the asset. And if they opt out before 36 months has transpired, we can get some money back on that on a pro rata schedule. And we do not have a righ
componenttext: Yes, so it's pretty simple. It's a month-to-month contract. We do advance some money for the rebranding of the asset. And if they opt out before 36 months has transpired, we can get some money back on that on a pro rata schedule. And we do not have a right of first refusal. We make this easy and hopefully, our performance is enough to keep people in, that they don't want to go somewhere else and we want flexibility to do what we need to do. So time I think we're coming up on 8.5 years of third-party management, Todd, and we've learned some things that work in terms of seller expectations and we've learned some things in terms of management, expectations, both coming and going, and we're very comfortable that our property level performance and the results we deliver on a month contract speaks for themselves and it's worked very well.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from George Hoglund from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from George Hoglund from Jefferies.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Follow-up on the transaction, are you seeing any change in the motivation of sellers in terms of is it -- have you seen more assets because of pricing is so good? Or are you seeing people looking to exit for other reasons as could be seen some private equ
componenttext: Follow-up on the transaction, are you seeing any change in the motivation of sellers in terms of is it -- have you seen more assets because of pricing is so good? Or are you seeing people looking to exit for other reasons as could be seen some private equity backers look to exit their investments and maybe sooner than one would think?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes. All of the above.
componenttext: Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes. All of the above.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's tough to comment on seller's motivation. I mean they all have a different motive.
componenttext: Yes, I think it's tough to comment on seller's motivation. I mean they all have a different motive.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's all of the above. It's pricing. It's motivation. It's everything.
componenttext: Yes, it's all of the above. It's pricing. It's motivation. It's everything.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as far as concerns about developments, I feel like people keep talking about it but it's kind of waning and now people maybe getting more concerned about an economic downturn in '17. How do you think storage would behave sort of differently this
componenttext: Okay. And as far as concerns about developments, I feel like people keep talking about it but it's kind of waning and now people maybe getting more concerned about an economic downturn in '17. How do you think storage would behave sort of differently this time around if we had a downtrend versus last time. I know some factors are different. You don't have the over supply issues you had last time. But how might revenue management impact things? Seems last time, basically, PSA just lowered rates significantly that impacted the industry. How are you think this would be different?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, it's Spencer. So what I would tell you is we're comfortable that self-storage is a great business to be in. It's recessionary system. We've already proven that. The industry has proven that. We were amongst the last to go into the recession, among
componenttext: George, it's Spencer. So what I would tell you is we're comfortable that self-storage is a great business to be in. It's recessionary system. We've already proven that. The industry has proven that. We were amongst the last to go into the recession, amongst the first to come out of the recession and the REITs are better equipped at this point than at any other time to acquire customers. The chasm between the haves and the have-nots has widened and the rate at which the chasm is growing is accelerating. So if there's a downturn, I'm highly confident the national players, the REITs are in the best possible position to capitalize and produce the very best results.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Wes Golladay of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Wes Golladay of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you got down with some pretty good success pushing rate and now you mentioned, you want to go build occupancy a little bit. Are you seeing anything in your predictive that has given you caution? Or is this maybe the occupancy move specific to certa
componenttext: I know you got down with some pretty good success pushing rate and now you mentioned, you want to go build occupancy a little bit. Are you seeing anything in your predictive that has given you caution? Or is this maybe the occupancy move specific to certain markets?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Typically, we're focused on just overall revenue growth. And our models have certain inputs. And so, you can tweak them slightly. I would tell you early on the year, it was focused more on revenue growth, meaning Street rate growth and now we're focusing
componenttext: Typically, we're focused on just overall revenue growth. And our models have certain inputs. And so, you can tweak them slightly. I would tell you early on the year, it was focused more on revenue growth, meaning Street rate growth and now we're focusing -- we tweaked the model slightly to focus more just on occupancy.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, you mentioned a lot of people active in the market. Is SmartStop actually getting a little more active? Are you running into them? And can you get some, I guess, meaningful management contracts later in the year?
componenttext: Okay. And then, you mentioned a lot of people active in the market. Is SmartStop actually getting a little more active? Are you running into them? And can you get some, I guess, meaningful management contracts later in the year?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: They continue to be active. I think we see them, we see the other REITs. We hope they continue to be successful. If we're not able to buy it, we wish them the best because we have a good relationship with them. I think it works well for both of us.
componenttext: They continue to be active. I think we see them, we see the other REITs. We hope they continue to be successful. If we're not able to buy it, we wish them the best because we have a good relationship with them. I think it works well for both of us.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeremy Metz of UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeremy Metz of UBS.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Ross here with Jeremy. You touched on it earlier, but I want to be sure I understood it. The vacates in the quarter were up 6.4% year-over-year. What exactly are you guys attributing that increase to?
componenttext: It's Ross here with Jeremy. You touched on it earlier, but I want to be sure I understood it. The vacates in the quarter were up 6.4% year-over-year. What exactly are you guys attributing that increase to?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's tough to attribute it to any one thing. Part of it, I would tell you, is the comp year-over-year. Last year had low vacates. It could be pricing. It could be a myriad of things so we have not attributed it to any 1 specific thing.
componenttext: It's tough to attribute it to any one thing. Part of it, I would tell you, is the comp year-over-year. Last year had low vacates. It could be pricing. It could be a myriad of things so we have not attributed it to any 1 specific thing.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also with more customers, Ross, you're going to have more vacates. We're at the highest occupancy we've ever been.
componenttext: Also with more customers, Ross, you're going to have more vacates. We're at the highest occupancy we've ever been.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean I think that's fair, although the 6.4% number did catch my eye a bit. I guess, I was wondering did you look at for those vacates, was there any trend in terms of average length of stay that was more short-term people, more long-term people, mo
componenttext: Yes, I mean I think that's fair, although the 6.4% number did catch my eye a bit. I guess, I was wondering did you look at for those vacates, was there any trend in terms of average length of stay that was more short-term people, more long-term people, more than 1 rent increase? Was there anything there that caught your eye?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, in fact, our average length of stay has increased. So we continued to increase our length of stay, but we have had some vacates but not anything concerning to us at this point.
componenttext: No, in fact, our average length of stay has increased. So we continued to increase our length of stay, but we have had some vacates but not anything concerning to us at this point.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ross, just 2 other points, if you look at an 8-year average, it's well within the bounds of being normal. And secondly, as Scott said earlier in this call, if you look at April, occupancy is going up, which means obviously, we're doing something righ
componenttext: Yes, Ross, just 2 other points, if you look at an 8-year average, it's well within the bounds of being normal. And secondly, as Scott said earlier in this call, if you look at April, occupancy is going up, which means obviously, we're doing something right. We can't look at just short periods of time. We need to look at this thing in terms of macro trends and we think 2016 is going to be strong year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Same type of question on the rental side. The number of rentals was down, but again it's because of your occupancy is higher, and you have fewer units. Can you give us some sense of what the traffic numbers looked like both at the store, on your web
componenttext: Okay. Same type of question on the rental side. The number of rentals was down, but again it's because of your occupancy is higher, and you have fewer units. Can you give us some sense of what the traffic numbers looked like both at the store, on your website, on mobile, your call center and how those numbers look year-over-year in the quarter?

componenttext: Year-over-year, our opportunities are within our normal range or expected range and our close rates were also within our -- within the expected or target ranges.

componenttext: Okay. So no discernible change. There weren't a lot of numbers in that answer. No discernible change in trend in terms of traffic?

That's a phenomenon and we've got a terrific mobile platform and it's part of what's helping us to deliver the kind of results we have been.

componenttext: So it's kind of mid- to high single digits but that depends on the time of year and the seasonality, Ross. Knowing the dead of winter, it's in the high single digits. At the peak of summer, it's low single digits, if it's not right on top of each other.

componenttext: Just one quick one on the dispositions, where those -- I know, they were small but the were those assets acquired in SmartStop deal? Or were those legacy Extra Space assets? And then what's keeping the management contracts the requirement of the deal?

componenttextpreview: So we purchased those in June of 2011 as part of our 15-property portfolio. Keeping the management contract was not a requirement but it obviously will lean towards a seller that was willing to do that.
componenttext: So we purchased those in June of 2011 as part of our 15-property portfolio. Keeping the management contract was not a requirement but it obviously will lean towards a seller that was willing to do that.

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

componenttext: Yes, this was a property that I would tell you it's probably typical of what you're seeing in the CLO deals and what you're seeing in the development. This is one that we thought we could get done. The developer was pretty comfortable that they could entitled. We put it under contract. We received some opposition from a neighborhood group and it fell out of contract due to the inability to get the proper project done.

componenttext: Probably it's some wierd risk, maybe a good thing for the industry?

componenttext: I would tell you performance is going to be a more on a micro market and depending on new competition within the market. But overall, it's pretty consistent between the boroughs and New Jersey, Northern New Jersey.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last one, are you -- can you comment on the SmartStop deal and what kind of growth you're getting in that portfolio and then why would now, if it's meeting your pro forma or better than expected?
componenttext: Okay. And just last one, are you -- can you comment on the SmartStop deal and what kind of growth you're getting in that portfolio and then why would now, if it's meeting your pro forma or better than expected?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you, slightly ahead of projections. Our disclosure to the Street was we originally projected that it would be about 5.5% cap rate in year 1 and I would tell you it's at or above that slightly. In terms -- we're actually getting a little bit m
componenttext: I would tell you, slightly ahead of projections. Our disclosure to the Street was we originally projected that it would be about 5.5% cap rate in year 1 and I would tell you it's at or above that slightly. In terms -- we're actually getting a little bit more in rate and occupancy is coming a little slower than we'd expected, although we saw some good occupancy growth in April.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Todd Thomas of KeyBanc.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Todd Thomas of KeyBanc.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you remind us what your typical rent increase pattern is for existing customers, what the thresholds are and how frequently you increase rents for existing customers? And has that changed at all over the last year or 2?
componenttext: Can you remind us what your typical rent increase pattern is for existing customers, what the thresholds are and how frequently you increase rents for existing customers? And has that changed at all over the last year or 2?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really hasn't changed in much the last decade. It's 5 months for the first rate increase. It's 9 months thereafter, 9 months thereafter, 9 months thereafter. We do have governors on that so if they get too far above the existing Street rate, we update
componenttext: It really hasn't changed in much the last decade. It's 5 months for the first rate increase. It's 9 months thereafter, 9 months thereafter, 9 months thereafter. We do have governors on that so if they get too far above the existing Street rate, we update the existing customer increase. But as we're pushing Street rates up each and every year, customer that may have dropped out of the eligible pool finds himself back in the pool. And so, as I said, between 9% and 10%, we do this every single month. And quarter-to-quarter, it provides meaningful revenue for this company. We like what we're doing and statistically, we've shown that a program that we have in place works in a good economy and a decelerating the economy. We haven't changed it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then Spencer, you mentioned that some of the move outs from rate increases, they tend to generally occur from customers that no longer need storage so their problem's been solved. Any sense for what percent of the portfolio might be disc
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then Spencer, you mentioned that some of the move outs from rate increases, they tend to generally occur from customers that no longer need storage so their problem's been solved. Any sense for what percent of the portfolio might be discretionary at this time or not really need storage any longer? Is there sort of a way that gauged that based on how long people say they need storage and they move in or some way to arrive at an estimate?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know the thoughts and intents. I don't know even how to quantify that, but what I can tell you, Todd, is that I think it's kind of in the mid- to low single digits of the customer base where there's any question mark surrounding whether they're go
componenttext: I don't know the thoughts and intents. I don't know even how to quantify that, but what I can tell you, Todd, is that I think it's kind of in the mid- to low single digits of the customer base where there's any question mark surrounding whether they're going to stay around or go.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. It seems much lower than what I think we had maybe talked about or heard back in '06 or '07 when I think it was closer to maybe 15% or 20%. Is that not an accurate assessment or something changed today versus maybe that last cycle?
componenttext: Okay. It seems much lower than what I think we had maybe talked about or heard back in '06 or '07 when I think it was closer to maybe 15% or 20%. Is that not an accurate assessment or something changed today versus maybe that last cycle?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, what I would tell you is over the course of a decade, a lot of the things have changed including our repository of data and our understanding of our customers. And without looking at some very specific numbers, I'm just having to give you off the top
componenttext: No, what I would tell you is over the course of a decade, a lot of the things have changed including our repository of data and our understanding of our customers. And without looking at some very specific numbers, I'm just having to give you off the top of my head but this is something that has not materially change and I don't know where that 15% to 20% number came from previously. I'd have to go back and look but I personally believe it's lower than that today considerably.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: To quantify this Todd, we'd be purely speculating or guessing. I mean, this is really a customer need or a customer decision here.
componenttext: To quantify this Todd, we'd be purely speculating or guessing. I mean, this is really a customer need or a customer decision here.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Extra Space Storage First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's call, Mr. Jeff
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Extra Space Storage First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would like to introduce your host for today's call, Mr. Jeff Norman, Senior Director, Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Takia. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website.Please remember that management's prepared remarks and a
componenttext:
Thank you, Takia. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website.
Please remember that management's prepared remarks and answers to your questions may contain forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act. Actual results could differ materially from those stated or implied by our forward-looking statements due to risks and uncertainties associated with the company's business. These forward-looking statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in the company's latest filings with the SEC, which we encourage our listeners to review.
Forward-looking statements represent management's estimates as of today, Tuesday, May 3, 2016. The company assumes no obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements because of changing market conditions or other circumstances after the date of this conference call.
I would now like to turn the call over to Spencer Kirk, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. We are off to a strong start in 2016. Revenue growth exceeded expectations coming in at 9.1%. Mild winter helped moderate expenses, leading to NOI growth of 12.3%. We ended the quarter at 92.8% occupancy, the highest in our company's hist
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. We are off to a strong start in 2016. Revenue growth exceeded expectations coming in at 9.1%. Mild winter helped moderate expenses, leading to NOI growth of 12.3%. We ended the quarter at 92.8% occupancy, the highest in our company's history at this time of year. We acquired 25 stores during the quarter, 6 of which were through an off-market transaction, where we bought out a partner. Pricing remains competitive and seller expectations are high, but we continue to find some accretive acquisitions in the open market and through our managed asset pipeline. We ended the quarter with 1,371 Extra Space branded stores. 
Per share, FFO as adjusted grew 25% year-over-year. This is on top of 21% growth the previous year, resulting in FFO growth of over 50% in 2 years. Our multifaceted strategy to increase shareholder value has 5 components. First, operating performance. 12.3% NOI growth is outstanding by any measure and for any asset class. Second, accretive acquisitions. We have strategically purchased $4 billion since 2012. Third, joint ventures. They have and will continue to produce an outsized return on dollars invested. Fourth, third-party management. Our program, the nation's largest, provides significant economies of scale and off-market acquisition opportunities. And fifth, an optimized balance sheet. These 5 components have enabled us to produce 22 consecutive quarters of double-digit FFO growth. 
I'd now like to turn the time over to Scott

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Spencer. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $0.86 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by a penny. The beat was the result of better-than-expected property level performance. Including costs associated with acquisitions, no
componenttext:
Thank you, Spencer. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $0.86 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by a penny. The beat was the result of better-than-expected property level performance. Including costs associated with acquisitions, noncash interest expense and a $4 million legal expense, FFO was $0.79 per share for the quarter.
Our same-store revenue growth was primarily driven by higher rates to new and existing customers and increased occupancy. Our 2016 same-store pool increased to 564 stores. The change in the same-store pool positively impacted our revenue growth by 30 basis points. Our top-performing markets included Atlanta, Dallas, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Tampa/St. Pete. All of which experienced double-digit revenue growth. Our slowest markets included Chicago, Memphis and Washington, D.C. Baltimore, all of which still grew revenue at 3-plus percent.
In addition to the strong performance of our same-store pool, our 2015 acquisitions, including SmartStop performed ahead of our underwriting. Our platform continues to maximize results. 
Year-to-date, we have $520 million closed or under contract, all of which are wholly-owned acquisitions. In addition, we have $191 million in joint venture acquisitions where we will invest $50 million in 2016. 
Based on our solid first quarter results, we have increased our full year guidance. FFO as adjusted is estimated to be between $3.71 to $3.78 per share. FFO is estimated to be between $3.59 and $3.66 per share. Guidance includes $0.05 of dilution from our 2015 and 2016 certificate-of-occupancy stores. It also includes 2015 and 2016 acquisitions that as anticipated, will require time to be brought up to our performance standards. Once they're performing at our portfolio average, these acquisitions should produce an additional $0.10 per share. 
I'll now turn the time back to Spencer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Demand is steady and while new supply is appearing in pockets, it is still muted across the country. We see exceptional performance in many markets and even our slower growth markets are posting steady revenue increases. As we indicated
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Demand is steady and while new supply is appearing in pockets, it is still muted across the country. We see exceptional performance in many markets and even our slower growth markets are posting steady revenue increases. As we indicated last call, we expect 2016 to be another strong year. 
Lastly, the outstanding results of Q1 are the direct result of 3,278 dedicated employees focused on and working hard to maximize shareholder value. To each of them, I say thank you. 
Let's turn the time over to Jeff to start our Q&A.

componenttext: We'll continue to invest across the U.S. I think on average, we want to keep our portfolio demographic similar to what we have today on average. So if we invest in one of those types of markets, hopefully, we're also investing in some of the very dense metropolitan areas with low -- high rent per square foot and good population and income demographic. So on average, we're not looking to decrease the average of our property portfolio.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, its Spencer. Big picture. This is a class-action in New Jersey. It has to do with consumer contracts, and it cuts across many, many industries and many, many companies. So we attended a mediation, where we reached an agreement on the parameters of
componenttext: George, its Spencer. Big picture. This is a class-action in New Jersey. It has to do with consumer contracts, and it cuts across many, many industries and many, many companies. So we attended a mediation, where we reached an agreement on the parameters of the settlement. We're in the process of finalizing the terms of that settlement and getting court approval. And we've accrued an estimated cost of settlement and that's what we've been talking about. We expect it to be a onetime expense. And it's going to be tough to better estimate until all of the negotiating has concluded but we've given you our best number and given you as much color as we can.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also just in terms of Chicago, it's a market that's underperformed the rest of the portfolio as of late. If you can just sort of address that. Then also, it seems though there's a large portfolio in the market that has about 30-odd stores i
componenttext: Okay. And then also just in terms of Chicago, it's a market that's underperformed the rest of the portfolio as of late. If you can just sort of address that. Then also, it seems though there's a large portfolio in the market that has about 30-odd stores in Chicago area. Does that market you would look to, or be interested in increasing your exposure?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Chicago, for us, over the long term has been a good market for us. Clearly, it's one of our focus markets. We like it. It's got great demographics. There's a lot of people there. Chicago, if you look a few years back, was one of our top-performing mark
componenttext: So Chicago, for us, over the long term has been a good market for us. Clearly, it's one of our focus markets. We like it. It's got great demographics. There's a lot of people there. Chicago, if you look a few years back, was one of our top-performing markets. I commented on earlier, its markets typically go in cycles. So we would look at Chicago as a long-term play. It's something that we would be interested in increasing our exposure in.

componenttext: Just a question on third-party management and that business, I believe historically, you said that adding or every 20 properties added about $0.01 to $0.02 per share of FFO. Is that still the right way to think about the direct contribution from those properties? Or has that changed at all?

componenttext: I think it's still pretty consistent. It's going to depend on where those properties are and the rent per square foot of those properties. If the property is in New York City, 6% of $30 rents is significantly more than 6% of $6 rents. So on average, I would say that's still correct.

componenttext: We continue to see strong demand. We were at industry trade show this past week, and our booth was full the entire time. We continue to talk to people. A good source recently has been some of the new construction coming on. So while new construction is coming into the market, we are bringing those on as management contracts.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one last one, if I may. Spencer, you've been plugged into the technology industry over the course of your career prior to EXR and at EXR, and I know you spent some time with the team researching and trying to understand the full service or
componenttext: Okay. And just one last one, if I may. Spencer, you've been plugged into the technology industry over the course of your career prior to EXR and at EXR, and I know you spent some time with the team researching and trying to understand the full service or valet storage operating businesses. Curious to get your read on what you think here. Is it positive for storage, just tapping into new customers, creating awareness? Or is it changing the way consumers think about storage on some level? And how the businesses or how the stores business may operate in the next couple of years? Just to appreciate your thoughts and comments a bit.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Todd. Just a few observations. First of all, valet or concierge or full service, however you want to characterize it, is a logistics business, and we are looking at it very carefully. My personal opinion is, I don't think it's likely to be a di
componenttext: Thank you, Todd. Just a few observations. First of all, valet or concierge or full service, however you want to characterize it, is a logistics business, and we are looking at it very carefully. My personal opinion is, I don't think it's likely to be a disruptor for self-storage. I think there is a segment of the population that will dial into it. And we're going to continue to monitor it. But today, we're not making any announcement that we're getting into valet because it is questionable whether it is a viable business model.

componenttext: I appreciate your comments on the different market performances. I was curious if you could provide a little bit more color around New York City and Houston? And they did great, but a little bit below the portfolio average. So just curious if they're seeing any impact from some of the supply.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Houston I think is probably a supply as well as an economic issue there. Our portfolio is about 2% below where it was a year ago. But even Houston has suffered from the energy downturn as well as some building. Our same-store pool is about 5% in revenu
componenttext: So Houston I think is probably a supply as well as an economic issue there. Our portfolio is about 2% below where it was a year ago. But even Houston has suffered from the energy downturn as well as some building. Our same-store pool is about 5% in revenues ahead of where they were last year and our bigger pool was about 7% ahead of where it was last year. So still solid performance, and last year those properties did really well. New York City as a whole, I would tell you, is not suffering from the overbuilding. I think overbuilding is going to affect in a micro market more than it is on the whole. The New York City on the whole is still 3 feet per square foot per person. It's still very low square feet per person in New York City.

It looks like you're fairly -- continue to be fairly active there. And we've heard some sort of mixed commentary around pricing and quality and be interested in your perspective as well.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Smedes, its Spencer. As you look at what's out there, first of all, there is a steady deal flow that's coming in. I think all of the larger companies that the REITs are getting called to bid. And with a steady deal flow coming in, we see asset quality
componenttext: So Smedes, its Spencer. As you look at what's out there, first of all, there is a steady deal flow that's coming in. I think all of the larger companies that the REITs are getting called to bid. And with a steady deal flow coming in, we see asset quality spanning the spectrum. The one constant in all of this is prices are high, really high. And you can have crappy assets that we think are just way out of market, and you can have really nice assets that even for us or maybe even some of the REITs are getting a bit too rich to transact. So we're looking for those accretive acquisitions, the opportunities that makes sense geographically and economically. And when they do, we're going to act. But quality spans the spectrum.

componenttext: I would tell you pricing continues to be strong. January, February, we are close to 10% above where we were last year. Going into March and April, we're still 6% to 7% above where we were last year, which for the spring is still pretty solid.

componenttext: So we pushed rate harder in January, February, and we gave a little bit on occupancy. You saw our year-over-year delta come in a little bit, and now we're kind of easing off that and going a little bit more with occupancy.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last question. Obviously, your management system -- your revenue management system is trying to optimize revenue. We get that. But just curious if we can see a little bit more move outs and less move ins this quarter? Any patterns or reason
componenttext: Okay. And just last question. Obviously, your management system -- your revenue management system is trying to optimize revenue. We get that. But just curious if we can see a little bit more move outs and less move ins this quarter? Any patterns or reasons why more people moved in or more people left, or less have moved in that you can point to that happened this quarter that might be unusual?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you part of it is the unusual comp from last year. Last year, you had a really odd thing in the northeast, where you had some pretty severe weather, which had very few move outs and very few move ins. So I think part of its year-over-yea
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you part of it is the unusual comp from last year. Last year, you had a really odd thing in the northeast, where you had some pretty severe weather, which had very few move outs and very few move ins. So I think part of its year-over-year. If you look at a bigger average, call it a 5- to 7-year average. We're right in line with the 5- to 7-year average in terms of move ins and move outs both.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could just give a little bit more detail on who those buyers are for those really low cap rates, and how much appetite you think there is out there from that competition.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: R.J., its Spencer. There's a lot of appetite for self-storage. I think it's no secret that it's probably the best performing asset class year in and year out. We're seeing pronounced competition everywhere we turn from trade buyers and nontrade buyers. An
componenttext: R.J., its Spencer. There's a lot of appetite for self-storage. I think it's no secret that it's probably the best performing asset class year in and year out. We're seeing pronounced competition everywhere we turn from trade buyers and nontrade buyers. And the only comment I would make is as we look at this, it's great to buy this asset class but once you've purchased it, somebody's got to operate it. It is operationally-intensive, and we think that that creates opportunity. And we'll just have to see how things play out but there's a lot of money chasing these assets.

componenttext: You're still looking at cap rates. Well, we typically underwrite them at 150 to 200 basis points. I would tell you that they bid more on the 150 basis point range. componenttext: So from our perspective, we will continue to look at markets, and whether it's markets that are difficult for us to operate in or whether they are markets that we feel maybe have reached their potential and/or they may have a need for CapEx that we put into those, so those are markets we'll look to dispose of assets. Some of these were a little bit more rural, and maybe not as core as we would hope for in terms of rent per square foot and the income of population demographics.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, as you know, we are trying to build a company and dispositions have not been something that we talked a lot about. But I think you can expect going forward that you will see us looking at the very bottom end of our portfolio and taking a really good
componenttext: Ryan, as you know, we are trying to build a company and dispositions have not been something that we talked a lot about. But I think you can expect going forward that you will see us looking at the very bottom end of our portfolio and taking a really good look at the economic performance as well as the physical characteristics of that particular bottom segment and rationalizing whether it should be on the portfolio. And I think you'll see some activity year in and year out at the bottom end. But it's not going to be a wholesale initiative on our part because we are trying to build, not dismantle.

componenttext: And our next question comes from Jonathan Hughes of Raymond James.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had one. Most of mine have been answered, but what renewal rate increases were you able to pass on to tenants in this first quarter? And then maybe how many left or vacated due to not wanting to pay those renewal rate bumps?
componenttext: Just had one. Most of mine have been answered, but what renewal rate increases were you able to pass on to tenants in this first quarter? And then maybe how many left or vacated due to not wanting to pay those renewal rate bumps?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's take the second piece first, Jonathan. Our existing customer rate increase program continues to show financially that we are hitting the sweet spot. Yes, there might be a few move outs, where people won't accept it, but the economics are compelling
componenttext: Let's take the second piece first, Jonathan. Our existing customer rate increase program continues to show financially that we are hitting the sweet spot. Yes, there might be a few move outs, where people won't accept it, but the economics are compelling in terms of the gain that we pick up from the high 90%, 95%, 98%, whatever it is that accept it and don't move out because this is a very sticky product type. Existing customer rate increases, it's in the 9% to 10% range quarter in, quarter out and it works well.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, are many just not leaving because they simply don't want to take the time to move their stuff out? Or is it just to get -- lack of available space?
componenttext: And then, are many just not leaving because they simply don't want to take the time to move their stuff out? Or is it just to get -- lack of available space?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's be realistic about this, Jonathan. If you're renting a unit and you get a rate increase letter that says your rent is going up $15, you are not likely to go get a U-Haul truck, take a Saturday morning, pack up your stuff, go down the street, unpack
componenttext: Let's be realistic about this, Jonathan. If you're renting a unit and you get a rate increase letter that says your rent is going up $15, you are not likely to go get a U-Haul truck, take a Saturday morning, pack up your stuff, go down the street, unpack your stuff, return the U-Haul truck to save $15. People just won't go through the effort to do that. It's an incredibly sticky product type. What we have found is a rate increase, more often than not, might finally signal to somebody. You know what, the problem that I was trying to solve has passed. Maybe I should move out. And that is, as I said a very, very small percentage, single digits, low single digits of the total customer base. So existing customer rate increases. It's a great program. We think we're operating in the sweet spot.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on discounts, what percentage of customers are receiving some type of promotion this quarter? And also, just wanted to get a sense of what you're budgeting for discounts this spring leasing season? You're obviously coming off a higher occupancy level
componenttext: Just on discounts, what percentage of customers are receiving some type of promotion this quarter? And also, just wanted to get a sense of what you're budgeting for discounts this spring leasing season? You're obviously coming off a higher occupancy level having smoothed out some of the Q4 seasonal dip. Just want to get a sense of discounts.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, discounts during the first quarter, about 75% to 85% of our customers moving in, coming in first time renters or new customers receive the discount. That is higher than it was last year. When we originally looked at the year, I think we had hopes tha
componenttext: Yes, discounts during the first quarter, about 75% to 85% of our customers moving in, coming in first time renters or new customers receive the discount. That is higher than it was last year. When we originally looked at the year, I think we had hopes that discounts would be flat. Now we're projecting they will be up slightly. But if you think of it in terms of whether discounts are up or down, our rates are up 5% to 10%. So clearly, if you rent to the same number of people, discounts will be up 5% to 10% over where they were last year. We'd hope to be able to cut them and keep them flat as a percent, but now we're seeing that they will be up slightly, and we're projecting the same into the spring leasing season, Todd.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And just one last question, I wanted to follow-up on the question about the assets you sold already. You're going to be managing on a third-party basis. Can you just go over maybe what the standard agreement you have in place is? Is it cancelab
componenttext: All right. And just one last question, I wanted to follow-up on the question about the assets you sold already. You're going to be managing on a third-party basis. Can you just go over maybe what the standard agreement you have in place is? Is it cancelable by either side? The reason I ask is I usually get into the third-party management with the potential to buy the property, but I wanted to see if you can get out of this since you're obviously disposing of it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's pretty simple. It's a month-to-month contract. We do advance some money for the rebranding of the asset. And if they opt out before 36 months has transpired, we can get some money back on that, on a pro rata schedule. And we do not have a rig
componenttext: Yes, so it's pretty simple. It's a month-to-month contract. We do advance some money for the rebranding of the asset. And if they opt out before 36 months has transpired, we can get some money back on that, on a pro rata schedule. And we do not have a right of first refusal. We make this easy and hopefully, our performance is enough to keep people in, that they don't want to go somewhere else, and we want the flexibility to do what we need to do. So time, I think we're coming up on 8.5 years of third-party management, Todd, and we've learned some things that work in terms of seller expectations, and we've learned some things in terms of management, expectations, both coming and going. And we're very comfortable that our property level performance and the results we deliver on a month-to-month contract speak for themselves and it's worked very well.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from George Hoglund of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from George Hoglund of Jefferies.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the transaction environment. Are you seeing any change in the motivation of sellers in terms of is it -- have you seen more assets because as pricing is so good? Or are you seeing people looking to exit for other reasons as could be se
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the transaction environment. Are you seeing any change in the motivation of sellers in terms of is it -- have you seen more assets because as pricing is so good? Or are you seeing people looking to exit for other reasons as could be seen some private equity backers look to exit their investments, and maybe sooner than one would think?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, yes. All of the above.
componenttext: Yes, yes, yes. All of the above.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's tough to comment on seller's motivation. I mean, they all have a different motive.
componenttext: Yes, I think it's tough to comment on seller's motivation. I mean, they all have a different motive.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's all of the above. It's pricing. It's motivation. It's everything.
componenttext: Yes, it's all of the above. It's pricing. It's motivation. It's everything.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as far as concerns about developments, I feel like people keep talking about it, but it's kind of waning and now people may be getting more concerned about an economic downturn in '17. How do you think storage would behave sort of differently th
componenttext: Okay. And as far as concerns about developments, I feel like people keep talking about it, but it's kind of waning and now people may be getting more concerned about an economic downturn in '17. How do you think storage would behave sort of differently this time around if we head into a downturn versus last time. I know some factors are different. You don't have the oversupply issues we had last time. But how might revenue management impact things? And seems last time, basically, PSA just lowered rates significantly that impacted the industry. How do you think things will be different?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, its Spencer. So what I would tell you is we are comfortable that self-storage is a great business to be in. It's recessionary system. We've already proven that. The industry has proven that. We were amongst the last to go into the recession, among
componenttext: George, its Spencer. So what I would tell you is we are comfortable that self-storage is a great business to be in. It's recessionary system. We've already proven that. The industry has proven that. We were amongst the last to go into the recession, amongst the first to come out of the recession and the REITs are better equipped at this point than at any other time to acquire customers. The chasm between the haves and the have-nots has widened, and the rate at which the chasm is growing is accelerating. So if there's a downturn, I'm highly confident that the national players, the REITs are in the best possible position to capitalize and produce the very best result.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Wes Golladay of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Wes Golladay of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll stick with that last question regarding the downturn. I know as you go down some pretty good success pushing rate and now you mentioned, you want to build occupancy a little bit, are you seeing anything in your predictive analytics that has given you
componenttext: I'll stick with that last question regarding the downturn. I know as you go down some pretty good success pushing rate and now you mentioned, you want to build occupancy a little bit, are you seeing anything in your predictive analytics that has given you caution? Or is this maybe the occupancy move specific to certain markets?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Typically, we're focused on just overall revenue growth. And our models have certain inputs. And so, you can tweak them slightly. I would tell you early on in the year, it was focused more on revenue growth, meaning street rate growth and now we're focusi
componenttext: Typically, we're focused on just overall revenue growth. And our models have certain inputs. And so, you can tweak them slightly. I would tell you early on in the year, it was focused more on revenue growth, meaning street rate growth and now we're focusing -- we tweaked the model slightly to focus a little more just on occupancy.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, you mentioned a lot of people active in the market. Is SmartStop actually getting a little more active? Are you running into them? And can you get some, I guess, meaningful management contracts later in the year?
componenttext: Okay. And then, you mentioned a lot of people active in the market. Is SmartStop actually getting a little more active? Are you running into them? And can you get some, I guess, meaningful management contracts later in the year?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: They continue to be active. I think that we see them, we see the other REITs. We hope they continue to be successful. If we're not able to buy it, we wish them the best because we have a good relationship with them. I think it works well for both of us.
componenttext: They continue to be active. I think that we see them, we see the other REITs. We hope they continue to be successful. If we're not able to buy it, we wish them the best because we have a good relationship with them. I think it works well for both of us.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeremy Metz of UBS.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Jeremy. You touched on this a little earlier, but I just want to make sure I understood it. The vacates for the quarter were up 6.4% year-over-year. What exactly are you guys attributing that increase to?
componenttext: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Jeremy. You touched on this a little earlier, but I just want to make sure I understood it. The vacates for the quarter were up 6.4% year-over-year. What exactly are you guys attributing that increase to?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's tough to attribute it to any one thing. Part of it, I would tell you, is the comp year-over-year. Last year had low vacates. It could be pricing. It could be a myriad of things, so we have not attributed it to any one specific thing.
componenttext: It's tough to attribute it to any one thing. Part of it, I would tell you, is the comp year-over-year. Last year had low vacates. It could be pricing. It could be a myriad of things, so we have not attributed it to any one specific thing.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also with more customers, Ross, you're going to have more vacates. We're at the highest occupancy we've ever been.
componenttext: Also with more customers, Ross, you're going to have more vacates. We're at the highest occupancy we've ever been.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think that's fair, although the 6.4% number did catch my eye a bit. I guess, I was wondering did you look at -- for those vacates, was there any trend in terms of average length of stay that was more short-term people, more long-term people
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think that's fair, although the 6.4% number did catch my eye a bit. I guess, I was wondering did you look at -- for those vacates, was there any trend in terms of average length of stay that was more short-term people, more long-term people, that you had received more than one rent increase. Was there anything in there that caught your eye?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, in fact, our average length of stay has increased. So we continued to increase our length of stay, but we have had some vacates, but not anything concerning to us at this point.
componenttext: No, in fact, our average length of stay has increased. So we continued to increase our length of stay, but we have had some vacates, but not anything concerning to us at this point.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Ross, just 2 other points. If you look at an 8-year average, it's well within the bounds of being normal. And secondly, as Scott said earlier in this call, if you look at April, occupancy is going up, which means obviously, we're doing something
componenttext: Yes. And Ross, just 2 other points. If you look at an 8-year average, it's well within the bounds of being normal. And secondly, as Scott said earlier in this call, if you look at April, occupancy is going up, which means obviously, we're doing something right. We can't look at just short periods of time. We need to look at this thing in terms of macro trends, and we think 2016 is going to be strong year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Same type of question on the rental side. The number of rentals were down, but again it's probably because your occupancy is higher, and you have fewer units. Can you give us some sense of what the traffic numbers looked like both at the store, on y
componenttext: Okay. Same type of question on the rental side. The number of rentals were down, but again it's probably because your occupancy is higher, and you have fewer units. Can you give us some sense of what the traffic numbers looked like both at the store, on your website, on mobile, your call center and how those numbers look year-over-year in the quarter?

componenttext: Year-over-year, our opportunities are within our normal range or expected range, and our close rates were also within our -- within the expected or target ranges.

componenttext: Okay. So no discernible change. There weren't a lot of numbers in that answer. So no discernible change in trend, in terms of traffic?

componenttext: Yes. That's a phenomenon and we've got a terrific mobile platform, and its part of what's helping us to deliver the kind of results we have been.

componenttext: So it's kind of mid- to high single digits, but that depends on the time of year and the seasonality, Ross. In the dead of winter, it's in the high single digits. At the peak of summer, it's low single digits, if it's not right on top of each other.

componenttext: Just one quick one on the dispositions, were those -- I know, they were small, but were those assets acquired in SmartStop deal? Or were those legacy Extra Space assets? And then what's keeping the management contracts a requirement of the deal access?

componenttext: So we purchased those in June of 2011 as part of our 15-property portfolio. Keeping the management contracts was not a requirement, but it obviously will lean towards a seller that was willing to do that.

componenttext: Yes, this was a property that I would tell you is probably typical of what you're seeing in the CLO deals and what you're seeing in the development.
