componenttext: And our next question comes from Jonathan Hughes of Raymond James.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had one. Most of mine have been answered, but what renewal rate increases were you able to pass on to tenants in this first quarter? And then maybe how many left or vacated due to not wanting to pay those renewal rate bumps?
componenttext: Just had one. Most of mine have been answered, but what renewal rate increases were you able to pass on to tenants in this first quarter? And then maybe how many left or vacated due to not wanting to pay those renewal rate bumps?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's take the second piece first, Jonathan. Our existing customer rate increase program continues to show financially that we are hitting the sweet spot. Yes, there might be a few move outs, where people won't accept it, but the economics are compelling
componenttext: Let's take the second piece first, Jonathan. Our existing customer rate increase program continues to show financially that we are hitting the sweet spot. Yes, there might be a few move outs, where people won't accept it, but the economics are compelling in terms of the gain that we pick up from the high 90%, 95%, 98%, whatever it is that accept it and don't move out because this is a very sticky product type. Existing customer rate increases, it's in the 9% to 10% range quarter in, quarter out and it works well.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, are many just not leaving because they simply don't want to take the time to move their stuff out? Or is it just to get -- lack of available space?
componenttext: And then, are many just not leaving because they simply don't want to take the time to move their stuff out? Or is it just to get -- lack of available space?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's be realistic about this, Jonathan. If you're renting a unit and you get a rate increase letter that says your rent is going up $15, you are not likely to go get a U-Haul truck, take a Saturday morning, pack up your stuff, go down the street, unpack
componenttext: Let's be realistic about this, Jonathan. If you're renting a unit and you get a rate increase letter that says your rent is going up $15, you are not likely to go get a U-Haul truck, take a Saturday morning, pack up your stuff, go down the street, unpack your stuff, return the U-Haul truck to save $15. People just won't go through the effort to do that. It's an incredibly sticky product type. What we have found is a rate increase, more often than not, might finally signal to somebody. You know what, the problem that I was trying to solve has passed. Maybe I should move out. And that is, as I said a very, very small percentage, single digits, low single digits of the total customer base. So existing customer rate increases. It's a great program. We think we're operating in the sweet spot.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on discounts, what percentage of customers are receiving some type of promotion this quarter? And also, just wanted to get a sense of what you're budgeting for discounts this spring leasing season? You're obviously coming off a higher occupancy level
componenttext: Just on discounts, what percentage of customers are receiving some type of promotion this quarter? And also, just wanted to get a sense of what you're budgeting for discounts this spring leasing season? You're obviously coming off a higher occupancy level having smoothed out some of the Q4 seasonal dip. Just want to get a sense of discounts.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, discounts during the first quarter, about 75% to 85% of our customers moving in, coming in first time renters or new customers receive the discount. That is higher than it was last year. When we originally looked at the year, I think we had hopes tha
componenttext: Yes, discounts during the first quarter, about 75% to 85% of our customers moving in, coming in first time renters or new customers receive the discount. That is higher than it was last year. When we originally looked at the year, I think we had hopes that discounts would be flat. Now we're projecting they will be up slightly. But if you think of it in terms of whether discounts are up or down, our rates are up 5% to 10%. So clearly, if you rent to the same number of people, discounts will be up 5% to 10% over where they were last year. We'd hope to be able to cut them and keep them flat as a percent, but now we're seeing that they will be up slightly, and we're projecting the same into the spring leasing season, Todd.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And just one last question, I wanted to follow-up on the question about the assets you sold already. You're going to be managing on a third-party basis. Can you just go over maybe what the standard agreement you have in place is? Is it cancelab
componenttext: All right. And just one last question, I wanted to follow-up on the question about the assets you sold already. You're going to be managing on a third-party basis. Can you just go over maybe what the standard agreement you have in place is? Is it cancelable by either side? The reason I ask is I usually get into the third-party management with the potential to buy the property, but I wanted to see if you can get out of this since you're obviously disposing of it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's pretty simple. It's a month-to-month contract. We do advance some money for the rebranding of the asset. And if they opt out before 36 months has transpired, we can get some money back on that, on a pro rata schedule. And we do not have a rig
componenttext: Yes, so it's pretty simple. It's a month-to-month contract. We do advance some money for the rebranding of the asset. And if they opt out before 36 months has transpired, we can get some money back on that, on a pro rata schedule. And we do not have a right of first refusal. We make this easy and hopefully, our performance is enough to keep people in, that they don't want to go somewhere else, and we want the flexibility to do what we need to do. So time, I think we're coming up on 8.5 years of third-party management, Todd, and we've learned some things that work in terms of seller expectations, and we've learned some things in terms of management, expectations, both coming and going. And we're very comfortable that our property level performance and the results we deliver on a month-to-month contract speak for themselves and it's worked very well.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from George Hoglund of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from George Hoglund of Jefferies.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the transaction environment. Are you seeing any change in the motivation of sellers in terms of is it -- have you seen more assets because as pricing is so good? Or are you seeing people looking to exit for other reasons as could be se
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the transaction environment. Are you seeing any change in the motivation of sellers in terms of is it -- have you seen more assets because as pricing is so good? Or are you seeing people looking to exit for other reasons as could be seen some private equity backers look to exit their investments, and maybe sooner than one would think?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, yes. All of the above.
componenttext: Yes, yes, yes. All of the above.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's tough to comment on seller's motivation. I mean, they all have a different motive.
componenttext: Yes, I think it's tough to comment on seller's motivation. I mean, they all have a different motive.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's all of the above. It's pricing. It's motivation. It's everything.
componenttext: Yes, it's all of the above. It's pricing. It's motivation. It's everything.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as far as concerns about developments, I feel like people keep talking about it, but it's kind of waning and now people may be getting more concerned about an economic downturn in '17. How do you think storage would behave sort of differently th
componenttext: Okay. And as far as concerns about developments, I feel like people keep talking about it, but it's kind of waning and now people may be getting more concerned about an economic downturn in '17. How do you think storage would behave sort of differently this time around if we head into a downturn versus last time. I know some factors are different. You don't have the oversupply issues we had last time. But how might revenue management impact things? And seems last time, basically, PSA just lowered rates significantly that impacted the industry. How do you think things will be different?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, its Spencer. So what I would tell you is we are comfortable that self-storage is a great business to be in. It's recession resistant. We've already proven that. The industry has proven that. We were amongst the last to go into the recession, among
componenttext: George, its Spencer. So what I would tell you is we are comfortable that self-storage is a great business to be in. It's recession resistant. We've already proven that. The industry has proven that. We were amongst the last to go into the recession, amongst the first to come out of the recession and the REITs are better equipped at this point than at any other time to acquire customers. The chasm between the haves and the have-nots has widened, and the rate at which the chasm is growing is accelerating. So if there's a downturn, I'm highly confident that the national players, the REITs are in the best possible position to capitalize and produce the very best result.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Wes Golladay of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Wes Golladay of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll stick with that last question regarding the downturn. I noticed you got down with some pretty good success pushing rate and now you mentioned, you want to build occupancy a little bit, are you seeing anything in your predictive analytics that has giv
componenttext: I'll stick with that last question regarding the downturn. I noticed you got down with some pretty good success pushing rate and now you mentioned, you want to build occupancy a little bit, are you seeing anything in your predictive analytics that has given you caution? Or is this maybe the occupancy move specific to certain markets?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Typically, we're focused on just overall revenue growth. And our models have certain inputs. And so, you can tweak them slightly. I would tell you early on in the year, it was focused more on revenue growth, meaning street rate growth and now we're focusi
componenttext: Typically, we're focused on just overall revenue growth. And our models have certain inputs. And so, you can tweak them slightly. I would tell you early on in the year, it was focused more on revenue growth, meaning street rate growth and now we're focusing -- we tweaked the model slightly to focus a little more just on occupancy.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, you mentioned a lot of people active in the market. Is SmartStop actually getting a little more active? Are you running into them? And can you get some, I guess, meaningful management contracts later in the year?
componenttext: Okay. And then, you mentioned a lot of people active in the market. Is SmartStop actually getting a little more active? Are you running into them? And can you get some, I guess, meaningful management contracts later in the year?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: They continue to be active. I think that we see them, we see the other REITs. We hope they continue to be successful. If we're not able to buy it, we wish them the best because we have a good relationship with them. I think it works well for both of us.
componenttext: They continue to be active. I think that we see them, we see the other REITs. We hope they continue to be successful. If we're not able to buy it, we wish them the best because we have a good relationship with them. I think it works well for both of us.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeremy Metz of UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeremy Metz of UBS.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Jeremy. You touched on this a little earlier, but I just want to make sure I understood it. The vacates for the quarter were up 6.4% year-over-year. What exactly are you guys attributing that increase to?
componenttext: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Jeremy. You touched on this a little earlier, but I just want to make sure I understood it. The vacates for the quarter were up 6.4% year-over-year. What exactly are you guys attributing that increase to?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's tough to attribute it to any one thing. Part of it, I would tell you, is the comp year-over-year. Last year had low vacates. It could be pricing. It could be a myriad of things, so we have not attributed it to any one specific thing.
componenttext: It's tough to attribute it to any one thing. Part of it, I would tell you, is the comp year-over-year. Last year had low vacates. It could be pricing. It could be a myriad of things, so we have not attributed it to any one specific thing.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also with more customers, Ross, you're going to have more vacates. We're at the highest occupancy we've ever been.
componenttext: Also with more customers, Ross, you're going to have more vacates. We're at the highest occupancy we've ever been.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think that's fair, although the 6.4% number did catch my eye a bit. I guess, I was wondering did you look at -- for those vacates, was there any trend in terms of average length of stay that it was more short-term people, more long-term peo
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think that's fair, although the 6.4% number did catch my eye a bit. I guess, I was wondering did you look at -- for those vacates, was there any trend in terms of average length of stay that it was more short-term people, more long-term people, that you had received more than one rent increase. Was there anything in there that caught your eye?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, in fact, our average length of stay has increased. So we continued to increase our length of stay, but we have had some vacates, but not anything concerning to us at this point.
componenttext: No, in fact, our average length of stay has increased. So we continued to increase our length of stay, but we have had some vacates, but not anything concerning to us at this point.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Ross, just 2 other points. If you look at an 8-year average, it's well within the bounds of being normal. And secondly, as Scott said earlier in this call, if you look at April, occupancy is going up, which means obviously, we're doing something
componenttext: Yes. And Ross, just 2 other points. If you look at an 8-year average, it's well within the bounds of being normal. And secondly, as Scott said earlier in this call, if you look at April, occupancy is going up, which means obviously, we're doing something right. We can't look at just short periods of time. We need to look at this thing in terms of macro trends, and we think 2016 is going to be a strong year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Same type of question on the rental side. The number of rentals were down, but again it's probably because your occupancy is higher, and you have fewer units. Can you give us some sense of what the traffic numbers looked like both at the store, on y
componenttext: Okay. Same type of question on the rental side. The number of rentals were down, but again it's probably because your occupancy is higher, and you have fewer units. Can you give us some sense of what the traffic numbers looked like both at the store, on your website, on mobile, your call center and how those numbers look year-over-year in the quarter?

componenttext: Year-over-year, our opportunities are within our normal range or expected range, and our close rates were also within our -- within the expected or target ranges.

componenttext: Okay. So no discernible change. There weren't a lot of numbers in that answer. So no discernible change in trend, in terms of traffic?

componenttext: That is correct. Our traffic on the Internet, our traffic to our call center were all within the expected range.

componenttext: Yes. I think maybe one of the things you're looking for mobile continues to be really important, and the growth rate of customers coming to us through mobile devices is growing well into the double digits. That's a phenomenon and we've got a terrific mobile platform, and its part of what's helping us to deliver the kind of results we have been.

componenttextpreview: So it's kind of mid- to high single digits, but that depends on the time of year and the seasonality, Ross. In the dead of winter, it's in the high single digits. At the peak of summer, it's low single digits, if it's not right on top of each other.
componenttext: So it's kind of mid- to high single digits, but that depends on the time of year and the seasonality, Ross. In the dead of winter, it's in the high single digits. At the peak of summer, it's low single digits, if it's not right on top of each other.

componenttext: Just one quick one on the dispositions, were those -- I know, they were small, but were those assets acquired in SmartStop deal? Or were those legacy Extra Space assets? And then what's keeping the management contracts a requirement of the deal access?

componenttext: So we purchased those in June of 2011 as part of our 15-property portfolio. Keeping the management contracts was not a requirement, but it obviously will lean towards a seller that was willing to do that.

componenttext: Yes, this was a property that I would tell you is probably typical of what you're seeing in the CLO deals and what you're seeing in the development. We received some opposition from a neighborhood group, and it fell out of contract due to the inability to get the project done.

componenttext: I would tell you performance is going to be a more on a micro market and depending on new competition within that market. But overall, it's pretty consistent between the boroughs of New Jersey. Northern New Jersey.

componenttextpreview: I would tell you, slightly ahead of our projections. Our disclosure to street was we originally projected that it would be about 5.5% cap rate in year 1 and I would tell you it's at or above that slightly. In terms -- we're actually getting a little bit m
componenttext: I would tell you, slightly ahead of our projections. Our disclosure to street was we originally projected that it would be about 5.5% cap rate in year 1 and I would tell you it's at or above that slightly. In terms -- we're actually getting a little bit more in rate and a little -- occupancy is coming a little slower than we'd expected, although we saw some good occupancy growth in April.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Todd Thomas of KeyBanc.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Todd Thomas of KeyBanc.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you remind us what your typical rent increase pattern is for existing customers, what the thresholds are? And how frequently you increase rents for existing customers? And has that changed at all over the last year or 2?
componenttext: Can you remind us what your typical rent increase pattern is for existing customers, what the thresholds are? And how frequently you increase rents for existing customers? And has that changed at all over the last year or 2?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really hasn't changed in much of the last decade. Its 5 months for the first rate increase. Its 9 months thereafter, 9 months thereafter, 9 months thereafter. We do have governors on that, so if they get too far above the existing street rate, we updat
componenttext: It really hasn't changed in much of the last decade. Its 5 months for the first rate increase. Its 9 months thereafter, 9 months thereafter, 9 months thereafter. We do have governors on that, so if they get too far above the existing street rate, we update the existing customer rate increase. But as we're pushing street rates up each and every year, customer that may have dropped out of the eligible pool finds himself back in the pool. And so as I said, between 9% and 10%. We do this every single month. And quarter-to-quarter, it provides meaningful revenue for this company. We like what we're doing and statistically, we've shown that the program that we have in place works in a good economy and a decelerating the economy. We haven't changed it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then Spencer, you mentioned that some of the move outs from rent increases, they tend to generally occur from customers that no longer need storage so their problem's been solved. Any sense for what percent of the portfolio might be disc
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then Spencer, you mentioned that some of the move outs from rent increases, they tend to generally occur from customers that no longer need storage so their problem's been solved. Any sense for what percent of the portfolio might be discretionary at this time, or not really need storage any longer? Is there sort of a way to gauge that based on how long people say they need storage when they move in, or some way to arrive at an estimate?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know the thoughts and intents. I don't know even how to quantify that, but what I can tell you, Todd, is that I think it's kind of in the mid- to low single digits of the customer base, where there's any question mark surrounding whether they're g
componenttext: I don't know the thoughts and intents. I don't know even how to quantify that, but what I can tell you, Todd, is that I think it's kind of in the mid- to low single digits of the customer base, where there's any question mark surrounding whether they're going to stay around or go.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. It seems much lower than what I think we had maybe talked about or heard back in '06 or '07 when I think it was closer to maybe 15% or 20%. Is that not an accurate assessment? Or something changed today versus maybe that last cycle?
componenttext: Okay. It seems much lower than what I think we had maybe talked about or heard back in '06 or '07 when I think it was closer to maybe 15% or 20%. Is that not an accurate assessment? Or something changed today versus maybe that last cycle?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, what I would tell you is over the course of a decade, a lot of the things have changed, including our repository of data and our understanding of our customers. And without looking at some very specific numbers, I'm just having to give you off the top
componenttext: No, what I would tell you is over the course of a decade, a lot of the things have changed, including our repository of data and our understanding of our customers. And without looking at some very specific numbers, I'm just having to give you off the top of my head that this is something that has not materially changed, and I don't know where the 15% to 20% number came from previously. I'd have to go back and look, but I personally believe it's lower than that today considerably.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: To quantify this Todd, we'd be purely speculating or guessing. I mean, this is really a customer need or a customer decision here.
componenttext: To quantify this Todd, we'd be purely speculating or guessing. I mean, this is really a customer need or a customer decision here.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shane. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call.In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website.Please remember that management's prepared remarks and
componenttext:
Thank you, Shane. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call.
In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website.
Please remember that management's prepared remarks and answers to your questions may contain forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act.
Actual results could differ materially from those stated or implied by our forward-looking statements due to risks and uncertainties associated with the company's business.
These forward-looking statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in the company's latest filings with the SEC, which we encourage our listeners to review.
Forward-looking statements represent management's estimates as of today, Thursday, July 28, 2016.
The company assumes no obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements because of changing market conditions or other circumstances after the date of this conference call.
I would now like to turn the call over to Spencer Kirk, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. It was another solid quarter for Extra Space. We produced same-store revenue growth of 7.6%, primarily from rate. Expenses increased 3.1%, which led to NOI growth of 9.4%. Quarter-end occupancy was very strong at 94.4%. FFO per share as a
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. It was another solid quarter for Extra Space. We produced same-store revenue growth of 7.6%, primarily from rate. Expenses increased 3.1%, which led to NOI growth of 9.4%. Quarter-end occupancy was very strong at 94.4%. FFO per share as adjusted grew more than 25% year-over-year. This exceptional growth is the result of solid operating performance, accretive acquisitions, joint ventures, third-party management and an optimized balance sheet. These growth components have produced 23 consecutive quarters of double-digit FFO growth and enabled a second quarter dividend increase of 32%. 
Year-to-date, we have closed over $0.5 billion in wholly-owned acquisitions, bringing the total property count to 1,412 Extra Space branded stores. Marketed acquisitions continue to be as competitive as we have ever seen. We continue to be disciplined and only transacts at levels that are beneficial for our shareholders. 
We've been particularly successful sourcing off-market transactions through our joint ventures, third party and other relationships. We believe that the 630 Extra Space branded stores, which are not wholly-owned, will continue to provide outsized acquisition opportunities. 
I'd now like to turn the time over to Scott.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Spencer. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $0.94 per share, meeting the high end of our guidance. Including costs associated with acquisitions and noncash interest expense, FFO was $0.91 per share for the quarter. Our same-store reve
componenttext:
Thank you, Spencer. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $0.94 per share, meeting the high end of our guidance. Including costs associated with acquisitions and noncash interest expense, FFO was $0.91 per share for the quarter. 
Our same-store revenue growth was driven by higher rates to new and existing customers. This is consistent with our guidance, which assumed minimal benefit from occupancy and discounts. The change in our same-store pool from 2015 to 2016 positively impacted our revenue growth by 30 basis points for the quarter. 
Our top-performing markets included Atlanta, Tampa/St. Pete and most of the state of California, all of which experienced double-digit revenue growth. The slowest markets were Chicago, Denver, Memphis and Washington, D.C., each of which still had positive revenue growth. 
Our 2015 acquisitions, including SmartStop, are performing in line with our estimates and lease-up times on our CofO deals are significantly faster than underwriting and our historical norms. Year-to-date, we have closed or have under contract to close $547 million of wholly-owned acquisitions. In addition, we have $248 million in joint venture acquisitions closed or under contract. 
Our investment in these JVs will be $81 million this year. All of these acquisitions are expected to close in 2016. During the quarter, we restructured 2 of our joint ventures to realize the value of our promote. The promote was exchanged for additional ownership in the joint ventures, increasing our equity position by over $40 million. 
At this time, we reaffirm our full year guidance. FFO as adjusted is estimated to be $3.71 to $3.78 per share. FFO is estimated to be $3.59 to $3.66 per share. This guidance includes $0.05 of dilution from our 2015 and 2016 CofO stores. It also includes 2015 and 2016 acquisitions that, as anticipated, will require time to be brought up to our performance standards. As these properties move towards our portfolio average, we expect outsized NOI growth. 
I will now turn the time back to Spencer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. While our unprecedented revenue and NOI growth have moderated, our ability to produce the industry's best FFO growth year in and year out has not moderated. This quarter's FFO as adjusted grew 25.3%. This is the result of our multifaceted s
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. While our unprecedented revenue and NOI growth have moderated, our ability to produce the industry's best FFO growth year in and year out has not moderated. This quarter's FFO as adjusted grew 25.3%. This is the result of our multifaceted strategy, which includes the industry's leading operating platform, the industry's most successful acquisition program, the industry's largest third-party management platform, the industry's largest and most successful JV program and a management team that clearly understands that growing FFO is our #1 priority. 
In closing, as we expected, our same-store performance has gone from phenomenal to excellent, and FFO growth is still phenomenal. 
Now let's turn the time over to Jeff to start the Q&A session.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Spencer. For our Q&A session, we are also joined by Joe Margolis, our Chief Investment Officer. [Operator Instructions] With that, we will turn it over to Shane to start our Q&A.
componenttext: Thank you, Spencer. For our Q&A session, we are also joined by Joe Margolis, our Chief Investment Officer. [Operator Instructions] With that, we will turn it over to Shane to start our Q&A.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim from SunTrust.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to ask you a couple of questions regarding the same-store revenue trends, the deceleration from about 9% to 7.5%. So if I put in perspective that 7.5% growth, we get it. I mean, it's still better than almost any other REIT out there. But, a
componenttext: So I just want to ask you a couple of questions regarding the same-store revenue trends, the deceleration from about 9% to 7.5%. So if I put in perspective that 7.5% growth, we get it. I mean, it's still better than almost any other REIT out there. But, at the same time, the decline is bigger than what we've seen from your portfolio in quite some time, and some of that growth also carries with it just good pricing momentum you've experienced over the past year, and it may not necessarily be reflective of new customer activity today. So my question is what is really happening on the front lines of new customer activity in terms of just your price sensitivity, and what's happening with Street rates year-over-year, promotion usage, things like that?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki Bin, this is Scott. The deceleration from Q1 to Q2 and from last year I would tell you is largely the result of no occupancy delta and not significant discount delta. So last year, we experienced call it 200 to 300 basis points of -- we benefited 200 t
componenttext: Ki Bin, this is Scott. The deceleration from Q1 to Q2 and from last year I would tell you is largely the result of no occupancy delta and not significant discount delta. So last year, we experienced call it 200 to 300 basis points of -- we benefited 200 to 300 basis points of occupancy and discount delta. This year, that's gone to minimal amounts. Our current street rates and our current achieved rates are still very solid. We're still getting call it 6% to 8% I think right. More recently, it's been about 7%. So we're still seeing very good street rates and achieved rate growth.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so if I take that into consideration, it sounds like, I mean, obviously, you had occupancy benefit loss. But are promotions almost going the other way, where is higher year-over-year? [indiscernible]...
componenttext: And so if I take that into consideration, it sounds like, I mean, obviously, you had occupancy benefit loss. But are promotions almost going the other way, where is higher year-over-year? [indiscernible]...

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you promotions are moving in line with rate. So, in other words, if rates are up 7%, discounts are up 7% also. So discounts may be up slightly but not significantly at all or not materially. It's moving with rate.
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you promotions are moving in line with rate. So, in other words, if rates are up 7%, discounts are up 7% also. So discounts may be up slightly but not significantly at all or not materially. It's moving with rate.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's between 60% and 65%, and that's not very much above last year. Last year was similar numbers, call it 60% to -- low 60s. And we also have to look not just at the percentage of customers getting the discount. You have to look at what discount they'
componenttext: So it's between 60% and 65%, and that's not very much above last year. Last year was similar numbers, call it 60% to -- low 60s. And we also have to look not just at the percentage of customers getting the discount. You have to look at what discount they're getting. So it may be they're getting the discount, but it's first month, half off or something smaller than they received last year.

componenttext: Sure, this is Joe Margolis. We have set up several programs with local developers where they, in targeted markets, they will source CofO opportunities for us to review, and we'll, in a programmatic basis, execute a number of those in joint venture in those markets.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a question on new supply, I guess, 2 questions really. One, any changes in the number of completions you're expecting in 2016 and '17? And then two, you've talked about -- we've heard about Chicago, Denver and Houston as seeing new supply lead to some
componenttext: So a question on new supply, I guess, 2 questions really. One, any changes in the number of completions you're expecting in 2016 and '17? And then two, you've talked about -- we've heard about Chicago, Denver and Houston as seeing new supply lead to some relative softness. So I'm just wondering if there any other markets on your radar at this point.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question, Todd. It's Spencer. First of all, our best guesstimate for 2016 is 700 properties likely to be delivered. 2017, maybe a little bit more. I think more importantly, in the last 2.5 years, if I could just provide a little color, 45 stores came
componenttext: Good question, Todd. It's Spencer. First of all, our best guesstimate for 2016 is 700 properties likely to be delivered. 2017, maybe a little bit more. I think more importantly, in the last 2.5 years, if I could just provide a little color, 45 stores came online within a 3-mile radius of one of our properties, and we still delivered outstanding performance. Within that same 3-mile ring, we see an additional 46 properties to come online sometime 2016, 2017. So yes, in some markets, there's been a little disruption of new supply in Denver, Boston, San Antonio, we're feeling the effect, but our other markets where it's not disruptive because there is virtually no new supply. You think of Northern California and Southern California, we're doing phenomenally well. So while there is supply, the effect has yet to be felt system-wide, and this is one of the beauties of geographic diversification.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I was just wondering if you're seeing any change at all on existing renters' behavior as it pertains to rent increases. Are you seeing any change in move-outs associated with rent increases at all?
componenttext: Okay. And then I was just wondering if you're seeing any change at all on existing renters' behavior as it pertains to rent increases. Are you seeing any change in move-outs associated with rent increases at all?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Existing customer rate increases continue to work beautifully, no change.
componenttext: No. Existing customer rate increases continue to work beautifully, no change.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: The other thing I would add to that, Todd, is customers are actually staying a little bit longer. We are seeing that our length of stay increase.

componenttext: Just looking at the back half of the year and same-store occupancy because last year, the end of 3Q, you had 93.6%, and end of 4Q is 92.9%. componenttext: At this point, we're assuming that it's going to be flat, 0 delta from last year.

componenttextpreview: Okay. Then also on some of the markets that had lower performance this quarter relative to the broader portfolio. Obviously, we just touched on some of the due to new supply, but are there other factors you are seeing could be characteristic of just certa
componenttext: Okay. Then also on some of the markets that had lower performance this quarter relative to the broader portfolio. Obviously, we just touched on some of the due to new supply, but are there other factors you are seeing could be characteristic of just certain individual markets that led to weaker performance, for example, like Memphis?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you new supply obviously affects it, but you've also got to look at prior year performance. So, for instance, Chicago today is not doing great for us a couple of years ago. And if you look at the 10-year average, Chicago has been very st
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you new supply obviously affects it, but you've also got to look at prior year performance. So, for instance, Chicago today is not doing great for us a couple of years ago. And if you look at the 10-year average, Chicago has been very strong for us. So I think that you can't continue to raise rates 16% year after year after year, and so I think that some of these markets probably just have a little bit of fatigue year-over-year, and you're coming up against some very tough comps.

componenttext: Okay, great. And just a bigger-picture question in terms of competition, full service providers. Can you give us any sense of what kind of market share those players may have in some of the top markets like in New York or San Francisco? And any views of the potential disruption of that technology or that business viability at this point?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, one, it's Spencer. Number one, for the full service valet, concierge, whatever you want to call it, we would say their market share today to the best of our knowledge in any market is de minimis, and for this company, we don't believe it's a viable b
componenttext: Yes, one, it's Spencer. Number one, for the full service valet, concierge, whatever you want to call it, we would say their market share today to the best of our knowledge in any market is de minimis, and for this company, we don't believe it's a viable business model.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And why is that? Is it the cost of transportation or what makes you so confident?
componenttext: And why is that? Is it the cost of transportation or what makes you so confident?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've studied it extensively. We have looked at the mechanics of what it really takes to provide that full service on demand at a price point that is competitive, and I think one, the fact that none of the largest storage REITs made any announcement
componenttext: Well, we've studied it extensively. We have looked at the mechanics of what it really takes to provide that full service on demand at a price point that is competitive, and I think one, the fact that none of the largest storage REITs made any announcement that they're getting into this ought to be a pretty good indicator that they don't see the dollars out there as well. There've been a lot of potential of the structures that have announced themselves in the past that would cause pain to the storage industry, and for whatever reason, it just has not materialize. We still think that storage offers the best value for a customer, and any time you try to put 2 people in a truck and transport it across the George Washington Bridge and do so at a cost-effective price point, we can't get there mathematically or economically.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I mean, I guess, my question is do you feel like facilities under construction are just opening faster? Or is there more -- are you guys discovering more on the margin? It seems like overall based on commentary from private participants as well t
componenttext: Okay. So I mean, I guess, my question is do you feel like facilities under construction are just opening faster? Or is there more -- are you guys discovering more on the margin? It seems like overall based on commentary from private participants as well that the pace of supply is starting to increase after many years of having a lot of gating issues? I mean, is that something that you would agree with or not?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there is more talk. There's more action, there's more supply, which is why if you go to one of my prior questions, it doesn't matter if 700 properties are 800 properties are being built or 1,000 properties are being built. What matters is if
componenttext: Yes. I think there is more talk. There's more action, there's more supply, which is why if you go to one of my prior questions, it doesn't matter if 700 properties are 800 properties are being built or 1,000 properties are being built. What matters is if those properties are both right across the street or next door or within 1 or 2 miles of your property that you're currently operating. As I indicated over 2.5-year period, we only identified 45 properties in our entire portfolio within a 3-mile ring. Smedes, if you think about a 3-mile ring in one of the boroughs of New York or downtown San Francisco, your trade area isn't 3 miles. We were generous on the 45 property count. The trade area might be a mile or less in a dense metropolitan area. And if you think about 46 properties that we have identified that are permitted and/or in some stage of construction to come out of the ground in 2016 or 2017, also within that 3-mile ring, yes, there is competition. Properties are being built. The question is when will we feel the impact? And today, the impact has been localized to a few specific markets, and there are many markets where it's not felt at all. So we're going to have to wait and see how it plays out but yes, there is supply, and it's coming the question is when will be the impact be felt system-wide?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. I just wanted to ask you, too, as you look at acquisition opportunities, are you seeing any of these particular difference between kind of primary markets and smaller secondary markets in terms of pricing or maybe the relative quality of portfolios?

componenttext: This is Joe again. Yes, there's a premium for secondary or tertiary markets. That, I think, is getting squeezed as people are unable to place their money into primary markets then all of a sudden, Raleigh looks good, and there is probably also premium in terms of quality.

componenttext: Our sales are driven by our view from 1 of 2 things. Our view of future growth opportunities. If we feel that there's a market that future growth is not going to be as robust as alternative places, we could put that money. And secondly, we're -- we have management inefficiencies maybe we bought a portfolio, and there's a property that is in a remote area we don't have sufficient scale to bring the full force of our management machine to, we'll put that on the sales list.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz of UBS.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, you touched on this a little earlier. I guess I kind of want to ask a little differently. If I go back to the last call, you talked about tweaking your model to focus more on occupancy heading into the peak leasing season. Obviously, occupancy stil
componenttext: Scott, you touched on this a little earlier. I guess I kind of want to ask a little differently. If I go back to the last call, you talked about tweaking your model to focus more on occupancy heading into the peak leasing season. Obviously, occupancy still very good at over 93%, especially relative to historical levels, but I think your expectations were for 75 to 100 basis points of occupancy growth this year. So I'm just wondering if you can give some color on maybe what happened here given that it doesn't really sound like it was a supply issue.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, our models obviously are going to focus on maximizing revenue. And when we look at the models early in the year and the end of last year and estimated where the model would take us, we estimated that we would have more occupancy benefit that
componenttext: Yes, I mean, our models obviously are going to focus on maximizing revenue. And when we look at the models early in the year and the end of last year and estimated where the model would take us, we estimated that we would have more occupancy benefit that we have had. The model has taken more rate and not pushed as much towards occupancy. There are certain markets where we have maybe tweaked the model a little bit in markets such as Denver, where we have seen some softening of occupancy, a couple of other markets where we've seen supply, we've had to do manual inputs into the model just because things were going on within that submarket or that overall market that the model, it's impossible for the model to read.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just sticking with the specific markets, can you just give us a little color on what's going on in Boston and Washington, D.C., particularly Boston seemed like revenue growth decelerated quite a bit. So I don't know if that's maybe just th
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just sticking with the specific markets, can you just give us a little color on what's going on in Boston and Washington, D.C., particularly Boston seemed like revenue growth decelerated quite a bit. So I don't know if that's maybe just the a tougher comps you alluded to earlier there.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you Boston is one that is up against tougher comps. We've seen some construction but not significant amounts of construction. Boston was very strong market for us last year. And Washington, D.C. is another market that has never been great. I
componenttext: I would tell you Boston is one that is up against tougher comps. We've seen some construction but not significant amounts of construction. Boston was very strong market for us last year. And Washington, D.C. is another market that has never been great. I wouldn't tell you it decelerated significantly. It's been steady.

componenttext: So just going back to rate and particularly just street rates. You talked obviously about this quarter rate being the primary driver and then back half no real change in occupancy year-over-year. So just mechanically and maybe strategically, in the fourth and the first quarter, as we move ahead, how should we think about your ability to push street rates relative to a year ago but also just relative to the overall rate? Really the question being could we -- is the 7% rate growth that you're seeing, could it be tough to do that in sort of 4Q, 1Q when you naturally pull back on rate?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you, Vikram, over time, I think it's going to be difficult whether that's 4Q or Q1, I don't know. I think it's going to depend a little bit on the strength of markets, but I think things will, at some point, revert more to the historical norm
componenttext: I would tell you, Vikram, over time, I think it's going to be difficult whether that's 4Q or Q1, I don't know. The beauty of a diversified portfolio, some markets will be stronger than others. You've seen some markets revert more to that historical norm already, and others are lagging.

componenttext: Okay. And just on payroll. I guess, your customer find one of your peers had slightly higher costs. I'm just wondering as the supply comes on or you've seen a decent certain markets supply come on, any pick up in attrition, maybe a manager saying there other opportunities and just broadly what are you seeing for wages?

componenttext: Our payroll and our turnover is very similar to prior years, and we are not seeing a lot of pressure on our wages. There's been some discussion about minimum wage, and it's not become an issue for us just based on where we pay our managers today already.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at moderating trend and what do you think the new normal, I guess, 5- to 10-year growth rate is? What is the ad trend growth rate that you guys will eventually get to?
componenttext: Looking at moderating trend and what do you think the new normal, I guess, 5- to 10-year growth rate is? What is the ad trend growth rate that you guys will eventually get to?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Wes, it's Spencer let me just give you a little performance. You've got revenue expenses. I'm going to focus on NOI because that's really where the rubber meets the road. Over the last 10 years, the simple average for NOI growth for the entire sector h
componenttext: So Wes, it's Spencer let me just give you a little performance. You've got revenue expenses. I'm going to focus on NOI because that's really where the rubber meets the road. Over the last 10 years, the simple average for NOI growth for the entire sector has been 5.3%. For Extra Space during that same 10-year period, it's been 6.7%. The fact that we just posted 9.4% ought to tell you that even with some moderation, we're still way above any historical norm, and I don't see us falling off a cliff by any stretch. Storage, if you go back to 1998 when I started with the company was used by about 6% of the U.S. population. Today, that numbers more than 9% of U.S. population. One of the questions is there's does top out at 10%, 11%, 12%, 13%? I don't know, but I think that at the end of the day, we're in a really good position to maximize revenue, and as I tried to stayed in my closing comments, look, NOI is only one contributor to our overall FFO performance. You'll get joint ventures, the most successful acquisition program in the industry and all of the other elements that I enumerated, which I'm not going to repeat, they all contribute to what we are trying to do, and that's FFO, and we've got multiple levers but that we're pulling the industry's best FFO growth year in and year out.

componenttext: It's just a good market for us. Again, I think the cyclical nature of it. I think Altanta is doing really well today. I think next year, it could slow little.

componenttext: So we've been successful in keeping our acquisitions pace primarily through off-market transactions and transactions we were able to generate through our management plus or joint venture pipeline. Pricing on the open market for some of the reasons you mentioned are -- it's difficult for us to get our minds around in general, and -- but we still think that these other avenues of growth are going to be available to us and will continue.

componenttext: Just looking at revenue management, can you share some of the specifics that revenue management was telling you in Q2? Just as far as pushing rate potentially the expense of occupancy. And as you look at the second half of the year or right now peak season, anything you can share from the past and the future about what revenue management is kind of pointing to right now?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Todd, it's Spencer. As you look at our revenue management algorithm, which has 56 different inputs, the whole philosophical underpinning is not about rate or occupancy. It's about maximizing revenue for a particular unit size code and a particular prop
componenttext: So Todd, it's Spencer. As you look at our revenue management algorithm, which has 56 different inputs, the whole philosophical underpinning is not about rate or occupancy. It's about maximizing revenue for a particular unit size code and a particular property based on what we know about those elements that are under consideration. So it's not rate, it's not occupancy, it's revenue.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: That's helpful. How about -- we've got an update in June at NAREIT about SmartStop. Any trends you can share? Any updates? And then when does that hit the same-store pool?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you in terms of trend in the updated NAREIT, I would tell you it continues to be ahead in revenues and behind on expenses. So when we said it's performing within our expectations, that's in terms of NOI. So revenues are better. Expenses
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you in terms of trend in the updated NAREIT, I would tell you it continues to be ahead in revenues and behind on expenses. So when we said it's performing within our expectations, that's in terms of NOI. So revenues are better. Expenses are higher. Majority of those expenses are timing. We probably spend more earlier on R&M and on some of the office supplies and repair and maintenance-type supplies than we originally estimated, and we hope to recover some of those throughout the year. But overall, revenues are strong and in terms of revenue pull it will go to in next year, January 2017.

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Paul Adornato of BMO Capital.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: One source of confusion among analysts and investors, I think, is just getting consistency in terms of the number of new stores opening, that's the supply pipeline. I know that you guys, I believe, have been trying to square and come up with either some sort of cooperative view or some third-party sources. Was wondering if you could provide an update on those efforts.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Paul, it's Spencer. Just a couple of observations. Number one, we do triangulate to the rest of our ability using broker data, our own external field observations. The hardware vendors data and just what we hear from other sources to come up with an e
componenttext: So, Paul, it's Spencer. Just a couple of observations. Number one, we do triangulate to the rest of our ability using broker data, our own external field observations. The hardware vendors data and just what we hear from other sources to come up with an estimate. And when we talk about the 700 properties being built in the United States at this time, you have to recognize there are 14 states we don't even do business in, and that's my earlier comment. It really doesn't matter what the number is. It just matters what the number of properties are that are being built within your competitive trade ring, whether it's 1 mile, 2-mile, 3 miles, and I don't know how as an industry at this point, we provide something that all analysts can triangulate on, but I think each of the individual public companies have generally been guided towards what's coming up out of the ground that is within the trade area. Because if it's not in the trade area, it doesn't matter.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Scott, you mentioned occupancy's now expected to be flat for the year. As tenants are getting stickier and use of storage becomes adopted by more people, do you think occupancy could surpass maybe 95% in the next several years? And is that
componenttext: Okay. And then, Scott, you mentioned occupancy's now expected to be flat for the year. As tenants are getting stickier and use of storage becomes adopted by more people, do you think occupancy could surpass maybe 95% in the next several years? And is that 95% the max? Or are you at max occupancy right now in terms of the same-store pool?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our philosophy and our understanding is we think we're approaching max occupancy, and the reason being is it takes time for units to turn. They typically sit vacant for a certain number of days before the new renter moves in. They don't necessarily pass e
componenttext: Our philosophy and our understanding is we think we're approaching max occupancy, and the reason being is it takes time for units to turn. They typically sit vacant for a certain number of days before the new renter moves in. They don't necessarily pass each other in the hall as one is moving out, and the next one is moving in, and that comes from a lot of factor, whether it's demand or whether that's our reservation policy at the time, where we allow someone to reserve a unit for maybe 7 days or 14 days depending on the occupancy of that unit. And then that reservation may or may not turn into a rental so at some point, you're theoretically full. We have estimated that to be around 95%, 96%. So 95% is it possible? Yes. Right, now we are not estimating we'll get it this year.

componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked and answered, but just in terms of kind of the acquisition pipeline, I understand you guys are looking a lot and being more disciplined about what you want to buy. But can you kind of just maybe help frame maybe kind of what's on the market, either actively or maybe quietly and just try and help us kind of think through how much pricing, I guess, has changed over the last year or so in terms of cap rates.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a good amount of product on the market. I would say that a lot of it is of lesser quality. We think cap rates have compressed a little bit this year, maybe 25 or 50 basis points. Clearly, there's a big premium for portfolios. We saw that in the la
componenttext: There's a good amount of product on the market. I would say that a lot of it is of lesser quality. We think cap rates have compressed a little bit this year, maybe 25 or 50 basis points. Clearly, there's a big premium for portfolios. We saw that in the large portfolio transactions that was previously announced by one of our peers, and it's just -- it's a competitive landscape. The secret of self-storage is out, and there is a lot of money chasing it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So I guess, Spencer, just if pricing is getting harder or more expensive on each deal, does that mean that kind of return hurdles have to come down in order for you to make these deals pencil? Or are you willing to just except kind of lower IRR tod
componenttext: Right. So I guess, Spencer, just if pricing is getting harder or more expensive on each deal, does that mean that kind of return hurdles have to come down in order for you to make these deals pencil? Or are you willing to just except kind of lower IRR today than you were say, a year or 2 ago? Or are you just able to squeeze more out of the portfolios and get better growth in order to maintain those high unlevered IRRs?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I would answer yes, to most of your questions, Steve. The fact of the matter is the market is red-hot. And for Extra Space, looking at 630 assets that are not wholly-owned that are in our system to us is a meaningful acquisition pipeline, and we c
componenttext: I think I would answer yes, to most of your questions, Steve. The fact of the matter is the market is red-hot. And for Extra Space, looking at 630 assets that are not wholly-owned that are in our system to us is a meaningful acquisition pipeline, and we can go after for years to come. And I believe that every market travels and cycles. And although things might be extremely competitive today, that necessarily won't be the case in future years. So for us, we're going to continue to use a multipronged approach to growing this company, and I've talked about several growth levers that we're employing to make sure that we deliver the industry's best result.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I'd maybe add one other possibility into kind of your realm of possibilities there, and that is the deal doesn't actually sell. At some point, pricing will get to that point if it continues to not meet people's IRR hurdles and their return hurdles,
componenttext: Steve, I'd maybe add one other possibility into kind of your realm of possibilities there, and that is the deal doesn't actually sell. At some point, pricing will get to that point if it continues to not meet people's IRR hurdles and their return hurdles, it's possible things don't transact.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, lastly, as was previously mentioned, you've seen we -- us do a few more transactions in a JV structure because we get a premium return through that structure, which helps kind of bridge the gap between market pricing and the return that we're
componenttext: And I guess, lastly, as was previously mentioned, you've seen we -- us do a few more transactions in a JV structure because we get a premium return through that structure, which helps kind of bridge the gap between market pricing and the return that we're trying to get for our shareholders.

componenttext: It differs by market, by property if you look at where we compete with brand-new properties that are opening. I'll give you couple of examples. We've had another property or 2,where for a year's time, we had flat or slightly negative growth, but we haven't seen them fall off the map by any sense here.

componenttextpreview: So you'd mentioned earlier that one of the biggest headwinds is the renter fatigue. And, I guess, when you look at, I guess, that'll be for the same-store portfolio. When you look at what's in the nonsame-store portfolio, I guess, including SmartStop, do
componenttext: So you'd mentioned earlier that one of the biggest headwinds is the renter fatigue. And, I guess, when you look at, I guess, that'll be for the same-store portfolio. When you look at what's in the nonsame-store portfolio, I guess, including SmartStop, do you view a large different in terms of how much renter fatigue is in that nonsame-store portfolio? I guess, that's part one. And then part two is, I guess, for new properties that come online from CofO deals, obviously, no renter fatigue in the new property, but do you see sort of more, I guess, rent growth potential going forward with these newly opened properties?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you in terms of properties we buy that we are managed as well as CofO properties there's more runway. Typically these properties are at lower rates than our properties. So we have the ability to push them for longer, and typically in a CofO s
componenttext: I would tell you in terms of properties we buy that we are managed as well as CofO properties there's more runway. Typically these properties are at lower rates than our properties. So we have the ability to push them for longer, and typically in a CofO store, we open at a rate that's below market. And so we have the ability to push rates longer because it takes them a little bit of time to get them up to street rates or what are normal market rates..

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, it's Spencer. There's one other thing on renter fatigue. I wouldn't take it too far because more than 50% of our customers walking in the door have never used self-storage ever. So they don't even know what they're up against. So it's the more mat
componenttext: George, it's Spencer. There's one other thing on renter fatigue. I wouldn't take it too far because more than 50% of our customers walking in the door have never used self-storage ever. So they don't even know what they're up against. So it's the more mature properties, where you've got a lot of really long-term tenants that you might start to feel it.

Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q2 2016 Extra Space Storage Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Jeff Norman, Senior Director of Investor Relations for Extra Space. You may begin.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shane. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call.In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website.Please remember that management's prepared remarks and
componenttext:
Thank you, Shane. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call.
In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website.
Please remember that management's prepared remarks and answers to your questions may contain forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act. Actual results could differ materially from those stated or implied by our forward-looking statements due to risks and uncertainties associated with the company's business. These forward-looking statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in the company's latest filings with the SEC, which we encourage our listeners to review. Forward-looking statements represent management's estimates as of today, Thursday, July 28, 2016. The company assumes no obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements because of changing market conditions or other circumstances after the date of this conference call.
I would now like to turn the call over to Spencer Kirk, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. It was another solid quarter for Extra Space. We produced same-store revenue growth of 7.6%, primarily from rate. Expenses increased 3.1%, which led to NOI growth of 9.4%. Quarter-end occupancy was very strong at 94.4%. FFO per share as a
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. It was another solid quarter for Extra Space. We produced same-store revenue growth of 7.6%, primarily from rate. Expenses increased 3.1%, which led to NOI growth of 9.4%. Quarter-end occupancy was very strong at 94.4%. FFO per share as adjusted grew more than 25% year-over-year. This exceptional growth is the result of solid operating performance, accretive acquisitions, joint ventures, third-party management and an optimized balance sheet. These growth components have produced 23 consecutive quarters of double-digit FFO growth and enabled a second quarter dividend increase of 32%. 
Year-to-date, we have closed over $0.5 billion in wholly-owned acquisitions, bringing the total property count to 1,412 Extra Space branded stores. Marketed acquisitions continue to be as competitive as we have ever seen. We continue to be disciplined and only transact at levels that are beneficial for our shareholders. 
We've been particularly successful sourcing off-market transactions through our joint ventures, third-party and other relationships. We believe that the 630 Extra Space branded stores, which are not wholly-owned, will continue to provide outsized acquisition opportunities. 
I'd now like to turn the time over to Scott.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Spencer. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $0.94 per share, meeting the high end of our guidance. Including costs associated with acquisitions and noncash interest expense, FFO was $0.91 per share for the quarter. Our same-store reve
componenttext:
Thank you, Spencer. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $0.94 per share, meeting the high end of our guidance. Including costs associated with acquisitions and noncash interest expense, FFO was $0.91 per share for the quarter. 
Our same-store revenue growth was driven by higher rates to new and existing customers. This is consistent with our guidance, which assumed minimal benefit from occupancy and discounts. The change in our same-store pool from 2015 to 2016 positively impacted our revenue growth by 30 basis points for the quarter. 
Our top-performing markets included Atlanta, Tampa/St. Pete and most of the state of California, all of which experienced double-digit revenue growth. The slowest markets were Chicago, Denver, Memphis and Washington, D.C., each of which still had positive revenue growth. 
Our 2015 acquisitions, including SmartStop, are performing in line with our estimates and lease-up times on our CofO deals are significantly faster than underwriting and our historical norms. Year-to-date, we have closed or have under contract to close $547 million of wholly-owned acquisitions. In addition, we have $248 million in joint venture acquisitions closed or under contract. 
Our investment in these JVs will be $81 million this year. All of these acquisitions are expected to close in 2016. During the quarter, we restructured 2 of our joint ventures to realize the value of our promote. The promote was exchanged for additional ownership in the joint ventures, increasing our equity position by over $40 million. 
At this time, we reaffirm our full year guidance. FFO as adjusted is estimated to be $3.71 to $3.78 per share. FFO is estimated to be $3.59 to $3.66 per share. This guidance includes $0.05 of dilution from our 2015 and 2016 CofO stores. It also includes 2015 and 2016 acquisitions that, as anticipated, will require time to be brought up to our performance standards. As these properties move towards our portfolio average, we expect outsized NOI growth. 
I will now turn the time back to Spencer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. While our unprecedented revenue and NOI growth have moderated, our ability to produce the industry's best FFO growth year in and year out has not moderated. This quarter's FFO as adjusted grew 25.3%. This is the result of our multifaceted s
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. While our unprecedented revenue and NOI growth have moderated, our ability to produce the industry's best FFO growth year in and year out has not moderated. This quarter's FFO as adjusted grew 25.3%. This is the result of our multifaceted strategy, which includes the industry's leading operating platform, the industry's most successful acquisition program, the industry's largest third-party management platform, the industry's largest and most successful JV program and a management team that clearly understands that growing FFO is our number one priority.
In closing, as we expected, our same-store performance has gone from phenomenal to excellent, and FFO growth is still phenomenal. 
Now let's turn the time over to Jeff to start the Q&A session.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Spencer. For our Q&A session, we are also joined by Joe Margolis, our Chief Investment Officer. [Operator Instructions]With that, we will turn it over to Shane to start our Q&A.
componenttext:
Thank you, Spencer. For our Q&A session, we are also joined by Joe Margolis, our Chief Investment Officer. [Operator Instructions]
With that, we will turn it over to Shane to start our Q&A.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
