componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Paul Adornato of BMO Capital.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: One source of confusion among analysts and investors, I think, is just getting consistency in terms of the number of new stores opening, the supply pipeline. I know that you guys, I believe, have been trying to square and come up with either some sort of
componenttext: One source of confusion among analysts and investors, I think, is just getting consistency in terms of the number of new stores opening, the supply pipeline. I know that you guys, I believe, have been trying to square and come up with either some sort of cooperative view or some third-party sources. I was wondering if you could provide an update on those efforts.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Paul, it's Spencer. Just a couple of observations. Number one, we do triangulate to the best of our ability using broker data, our own external field observations, the hardware vendors' data and just what we hear from other sources to come up with an
componenttext: So, Paul, it's Spencer. Just a couple of observations. Number one, we do triangulate to the best of our ability using broker data, our own external field observations, the hardware vendors' data and just what we hear from other sources to come up with an estimate. And when we talk about 700 properties being built in the United States at this time, you have to recognize there are 14 states we don't even do business in. And back to my earlier comment, it really doesn't matter what the number is. It just matters what the number of properties are that are being built within your competitive trade ring, whether it's 1 mile, 2 mile, 3 miles. And I don't know how -- as an industry at this point, we provide something that all analysts can triangulate on. But I think each of the individual public companies have generally been guiding toward what's coming up out of the ground that is within the trade area. Because if it's not in the trade area, it doesn't matter.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jonathan Hughes of Raymond James.

componenttext: I know you mentioned earlier that SmartStop was ahead of revenues and behind on expenses. But could you give us an update on maybe where occupancy is today?

componenttextpreview: I actually don't have that right in front of me, but I know it's been trending in line with our estimates.
componenttext: I actually don't have that right in front of me, but I know it's been trending in line with our estimates.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Scott, you mentioned occupancy's now expected to be flat for the year. As tenants are getting stickier and use of storage becomes adopted by more people, do you think occupancy could surpass maybe 95% in the next several years? And is that
componenttext: Okay. And then, Scott, you mentioned occupancy's now expected to be flat for the year. As tenants are getting stickier and use of storage becomes adopted by more people, do you think occupancy could surpass maybe 95% in the next several years? And is that 95% the max? Or are you at max occupancy right now in terms of the same-store pool?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our philosophy and our understanding is we think that we are approaching max occupancy. And the reason being is it takes time for units to turn. They typically sit vacant for a certain number of days before the new renter moves in. They don't necessarily
componenttext: Our philosophy and our understanding is we think that we are approaching max occupancy. And the reason being is it takes time for units to turn. They typically sit vacant for a certain number of days before the new renter moves in. They don't necessarily pass each other in the hall as one is moving out and the next one is moving in. And that comes from a lot of factors, whether it's demand or whether that's our reservation policy at the time, where we allow someone to reserve a unit for maybe 7 days or 14 days depending on the occupancy of that unit and then that reservation may or may not turn into a rental. So at some point, you are theoretically full. We have estimated that to be around 95 -- 96%. So 95%, is it possible? Yes. Right now we're not estimating we'll hit it this year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked and answered. But just in terms of kind of the acquisition pipeline, I understand you guys are looking at a lot and being more disciplined about what you want to buy. But can you kind of just maybe help frame maybe kind of what's on the market, either actively or maybe quietly? And just try and help us kind of think through how much pricing, I guess, has changed over the last year or so in terms of cap rates.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a good amount of product on the market. I would say that a lot of it is of lesser quality. We think cap rates have compressed a little bit this year, maybe 25 or 50 basis points. Clearly, there's a big premium for portfolios. We saw that in the la
componenttext: There's a good amount of product on the market. I would say that a lot of it is of lesser quality. We think cap rates have compressed a little bit this year, maybe 25 or 50 basis points. Clearly, there's a big premium for portfolios. We saw that in the large portfolio transaction that was previously announced by one of our peers. And it's just -- it's a competitive landscape. The secret of self-storage is out, and there's a lot of money chasing it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So I guess, Spencer, just if pricing is getting harder or more expensive on each deal, does that mean that kind of return hurdles have to come down in order for you to make these deals pencil? Or are you willing to just except kind of lower IRRs to
componenttext: Right. So I guess, Spencer, just if pricing is getting harder or more expensive on each deal, does that mean that kind of return hurdles have to come down in order for you to make these deals pencil? Or are you willing to just except kind of lower IRRs today than you were, say, a year or 2 ago? Or are you just able to squeeze more out of the portfolios and get better growth in order to maintain those high unlevered IRRs?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I would answer yes to most of your questions of that, Steve. The fact of the matter is the market is red-hot. And for Extra Space looking at 630 assets that are not wholly-owned that are in our system to us is a meaningful acquisition pipeline tha
componenttext: I think I would answer yes to most of your questions of that, Steve. The fact of the matter is the market is red-hot. And for Extra Space looking at 630 assets that are not wholly-owned that are in our system to us is a meaningful acquisition pipeline that we can go after for years to come. And I believe that every market travels in cycles. And although things might be extremely competitive today, that necessarily won't be the case in future years. So for us, we're going to continue to use a multipronged approach to growing this company. And I've talked about several growth levers that we're employing to make sure that we deliver the industry's best result.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I'd maybe add one other possibility to kind of your realm of possibilities there, and that is the deal doesn't actually sell. At some point, pricing will get to that point, if it continues to not meet people's IRR hurdles and their return hurdles,
componenttext: Steve, I'd maybe add one other possibility to kind of your realm of possibilities there, and that is the deal doesn't actually sell. At some point, pricing will get to that point, if it continues to not meet people's IRR hurdles and their return hurdles, it's possible things don't transact.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess lastly, as was previously mentioned, you've seen we -- us do a few more transactions in a JV structure because we get a premium return through that structure, which helps kind of bridge the gap between market pricing and the return that we're
componenttext: And I guess lastly, as was previously mentioned, you've seen we -- us do a few more transactions in a JV structure because we get a premium return through that structure, which helps kind of bridge the gap between market pricing and the return that we're trying to get for our shareholders.

componenttext: And we have a follow-up question from the line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones here. headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it -- obviously, it differs by market, by property. If you look at where we compete with brand-new properties that are opening -- I'll give you a couple of examples. We had one up in Harlem, where we had a property opened by one of our peers, a large p
componenttext: So it -- obviously, it differs by market, by property. If you look at where we compete with brand-new properties that are opening -- I'll give you a couple of examples. We had one up in Harlem, where we had a property opened by one of our peers, a large property that filled up quickly. Our property still grew at almost 10% that year. Now that's not to say it couldn't have grown at 15%, but we still had very solid growth. We've had another property or 2, where for a year's time, we had flat or slightly negative growth, but we haven't seen them fall off the map by any sense here.

componenttextpreview: So we're pretty happy with where we are. We don't see it going up significantly. But we -- if you look at the markets historically, at least recently, the bets on variable rate debt have been right, and we feel like it's at a point that it's good for our
componenttext: So we're pretty happy with where we are. We don't see it going up significantly. But we -- if you look at the markets historically, at least recently, the bets on variable rate debt have been right, and we feel like it's at a point that it's good for our shareholders as well as prudent.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have a follow-up question from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.
componenttext: And we have a follow-up question from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you'd mentioned earlier that one of the kind of I guess biggest headwinds is the renter fatigue. And I guess, when you look at -- I guess, that'll be for the same-store portfolio. When you look at what's in the nonsame-store portfolio, I guess, includi
componenttext: So you'd mentioned earlier that one of the kind of I guess biggest headwinds is the renter fatigue. And I guess, when you look at -- I guess, that'll be for the same-store portfolio. When you look at what's in the nonsame-store portfolio, I guess, including your SmartStop, do you view a large difference in terms of how much renter fatigue is in that nonsame-store portfolio? I guess, that's part one. And then part two is, I guess, for new properties that come online from the CofO deals, obviously, no renter fatigue in a new property. But do you see sort of more, I guess, rent growth potential going forward with these newly-opened properties?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you in terms of properties we buy that were not managed as well as CofO properties there's more runway. Typically these properties are at lower rates than our properties. So we have the ability to push them for longer. And typically, in a Cof
componenttext: I would tell you in terms of properties we buy that were not managed as well as CofO properties there's more runway. Typically these properties are at lower rates than our properties. So we have the ability to push them for longer. And typically, in a CofO store, we open at a rate that's below market. And so we have the ability to push rates longer because it takes them a little bit of time to get them up to street rates or what are normal market rates.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, it's Spencer. There's one other thing on this renter fatigue. I wouldn't take it too far because more than 50% of our customers walking in the door have never used self-storage ever. So they don't even know what they're up against. So it's the mor
componenttext: George, it's Spencer. There's one other thing on this renter fatigue. I wouldn't take it too far because more than 50% of our customers walking in the door have never used self-storage ever. So they don't even know what they're up against. So it's the more mature properties where you've got a lot of really long-term tenants that you might start to feel it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Extra Space Storage Inc. Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's program is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's program, Jeff Norman, Senior Director of Investor Relations for Extra Space Storage.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website. Please remember that management's prepared remarks and
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website. Please remember that management's prepared remarks and the answers to your questions may contain forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act. Actual results could differ materially from those stated or implied by our forward-looking statements due to risks and uncertainties associated with the company's business. These forward-looking statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in the company's latest filings with the SEC, which we encourage our listeners to review.
Forward-looking statements represent management's estimates as of today, Thursday, October 27, 2016. The company assumes no obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements because of changing market conditions or other circumstances after the date of this conference call. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Spencer Kirk, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. As many of you know, last month, I announced that I will be retiring at the end of the year, and that I will be succeeded by our Chief Investment Officer, Joe Margolis. I've had the opportunity to work with Joe for more than 18 years. He
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. As many of you know, last month, I announced that I will be retiring at the end of the year, and that I will be succeeded by our Chief Investment Officer, Joe Margolis. I've had the opportunity to work with Joe for more than 18 years. He was instrumental in structuring our first JV with Prudential in 1998. He served on our Board of Directors for more than a decade, and he has excelled in his role as our Chief Investment Officer. He has the right balance of real estate expertise and leadership skills to lead Extra Space in its continued growth and success. 
So at this time, I'd like to turn the time over to Joe.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Spencer. Good afternoon, everybody. It has been great to meet with many of you face to face since we announced Spencer's retirement, and I look forward to getting to know you better through future interactions. It was another strong quarter f
componenttext:
Thank you, Spencer. Good afternoon, everybody. It has been great to meet with many of you face to face since we announced Spencer's retirement, and I look forward to getting to know you better through future interactions. 
It was another strong quarter for Extra Space. FFO per share as adjusted grew 26% year-over-year. This growth was the result of more than solid operating performance. It was also fueled by accretive acquisitions, joint ventures, third-party management and an optimized balance sheet. We are focused on using all of these levers to continue to grow shareholder value. 
Operationally, we continue to push rates to new and existing customers in the quarter and experienced average street rate of growth of approximately 7%, similar to 2015. This growth was partially offset by an increase in bad debt and discounts, which resulted in same-store revenue growth of 6.1%. 
Discounts, while still very low from our historical measure, are up from an all-time low in 2015. Expenses increased only 1.4%, which led to NOI growth of 7.8%. Quarter-end occupancy was strong at 93%. 
Year-to-date, we have acquired $825 million in wholly-owned stores. With very few exceptions, these acquisitions were not broadly marketed but came from our JV, managed and other relationships. The largest of the off-market transactions closed on September 16, when we purchased Prudential's majority interest in 23 stores for $238 million. 
Concurrently, we sold our minority interest to Prudential and the remaining 42 stores in the joint venture for $35 million. We will continue to manage these stores. 
In addition, we are under agreement with a JV partner to purchase its majority interest in 11 stores for approximately $153 million. We plan to close this transaction in the fourth quarter, which will result in wholly-owned acquisitions of $1 billion in 2016.
We also expect to close $255 million in CofO acquisitions in 2016. $90 million of these will be wholly owned and the remainder will be in joint ventures, with our investment in these ventures totaling $53 million. Our JV strategy and our CofO program are working and are creating value year in and year out. 
I would now like to turn the time over to Scott.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $1.02 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by $0.02. Including costs associated with acquisitions and noncash interest expense, FFO was $1 per share for the quarter. The beat was primari
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $1.02 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by $0.02. Including costs associated with acquisitions and noncash interest expense, FFO was $1 per share for the quarter. The beat was primarily the result of stronger-than-anticipated performance from our 2015 acquisitions, specifically SmartStop. We also benefited from the collection of $1 million in business interruption insurance proceeds. 
As Joe mentioned, our same-store revenue growth was driven by higher rates to new and existing customers. This is consistent with our guidance, which assume no benefit from occupancy and a headwind from discounts in the second half of 2016. We continue to have solid revenue and NOI growth throughout our diversified portfolio.
Our top-performing markets in the quarter included Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Sacramento, San Diego and Tampa [ph], with revenue growth in the high single-digit. The slowest markets were Boston, Chicago, Denver, Houston and Memphis. With the exception of Denver, which represents about 1% of our revenue, all of our markets showed positive revenue growth year-over-year.
Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we completed a $1.15 billion unsecured credit facility. The facility consists of a $500 million revolving line of credit; a 5-year, $430 million term loan; and a 7-year, $220 million term loan. The credit facility has an accordion feature that allows us to increase total capacity to $1.5 billion. 
At closing, we drew $300 million on the 5-year tranche and paid off and terminated 3 of our 4 bilateral revolving lines of credit. The 5- and 7-year tranches have delayed draw features. We will access the remaining available term balances as needed to finance future acquisitions and to pay off debt.
This unsecured facility further diversifies our capital structure and reduces our average interest rate. Our goal is to have access to multiple types of capital to ladder [ph] these and to maintain financial stability. This credit facility helps accomplish all of these goals.
Due to the outperformance of our 2015 acquisitions, we are increasing our annual FFO guidance. FFO as adjusted is now estimated to be $3.78 to $3.80 per share. FFO is now estimated to be $3.63 to $3.65 per share. This guidance includes $0.05 of dilution from our 2015 and 2016 CofO stores. It also includes acquisitions that, as anticipated, will require time to be brought up to our performance standards. As these properties move towards our portfolio average, we expect outsized NOI growth. 
I will now turn the time back to Spencer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. This is my final earnings call as the CEO of Extra Space. I've enjoyed working with each of you, and I am grateful for the relationships and friendships that have been developed over the years. Going forward, I will continue to be activel
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. This is my final earnings call as the CEO of Extra Space. I've enjoyed working with each of you, and I am grateful for the relationships and friendships that have been developed over the years. 
Going forward, I will continue to be actively involved as a member of the board, and I will remain the company's largest individual shareholder. My interests are perfectly aligned with those of our shareholders. 
Thinking back 7.5 years ago when I took over as CEO, it wasn't about my predecessor, Ken Woolley, and today, it isn't about Spencer Kirk. It's always been about our competent and capable executive team, which has an average tenure of 14 years. I'm 100% comfortable that Joe Margolis is the right person at the right time to lead this very strong team. Our unique structure and our ability to execute a clear business strategy has allowed us to be among the fastest-growing REITs in the nation. None of that changes with this transition. 
Over the last 5 years, we have profitably acquired over $5 billion of real estate. These acquisitions alone would constitute one of the largest storage companies in the nation. When you combine that kind of external growth with the industry's best operating platform, which just delivered its 24th consecutive quarter of double-digit FFO growth, Extra Space is well positioned to continue to deliver outsized growth for years to come. 
With that, let's turn it over to Jeff to start the Q&A.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Spencer. [Operator Instructions] With that, we'll turn it over to Jonathan to start our Q&A.
componenttext: Thank you, Spencer. [Operator Instructions] With that, we'll turn it over to Jonathan to start our Q&A.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of R.J. Milligan from Baird.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First off, congratulations, Spencer. It's been great working with you. So congratulations on your retirement.
componenttext: First off, congratulations, Spencer. It's been great working with you. So congratulations on your retirement.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I had a question in terms of the acquisitions and sort of plans for long-term funding. Obviously, a lot more acquisitions this quarter and for the year more than planned. But given where the stock price is trading, curious what your plans are for f
componenttext: Scott, I had a question in terms of the acquisitions and sort of plans for long-term funding. Obviously, a lot more acquisitions this quarter and for the year more than planned. But given where the stock price is trading, curious what your plans are for funding those acquisitions and if you'd be comfortable raising equity at the current price.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, I would tell you that we don't look at our current stock price anytime we make an acquisition decision. It's not made with a short-term cost of capital in mind. We always look at the long-term cost. So we've always tried to have many so
componenttext: Yes, first of all, I would tell you that we don't look at our current stock price anytime we make an acquisition decision. It's not made with a short-term cost of capital in mind. We always look at the long-term cost. So we've always tried to have many sources of capital. And right now, I would tell you that we still do. Debt is an option. We just closed this facility that gives us a fair amount of capacity. The preferred market's still a very good. And our stock price, we don't like it as much today as we have in the past, but I think that we will always look to access the cheapest cost of capital which could also include joint ventures or even proceeds from the sales of properties.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So would you be willing to increase debt levels for the short term until maybe you have a better stock price?
componenttext: So would you be willing to increase debt levels for the short term until maybe you have a better stock price?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marginally, yes, we would.
componenttext: Marginally, yes, we would.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes the line of Juan Sanabria from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Juan Sanabria from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just hoping you could talk a little bit about the state of demand. If I look at Page 20 of your supplemental, it looks like rentable square feet on a same-store basis declined year-over-year for the 3 months and for the 9 months, and you kind of tal
componenttext: I was just hoping you could talk a little bit about the state of demand. If I look at Page 20 of your supplemental, it looks like rentable square feet on a same-store basis declined year-over-year for the 3 months and for the 9 months, and you kind of talked about concessions going up. So just curious about the health of demand and kind of what you're having to offer to get people to sign the leases.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm assuming you're looking at the rentals and vacates in our supplementals. The first thing I'd -- we always tell people to be careful with looking at rentals and vacates. It depends a little bit on what happened last year. We focus more on occupanc
componenttext: Yes. I'm assuming you're looking at the rentals and vacates in our supplementals. The first thing I'd -- we always tell people to be careful with looking at rentals and vacates. It depends a little bit on what happened last year. We focus more on occupancy and revenue growth. I would tell you demand is still solid. We are very near our record high occupancy for this time of year. Last year was our best year ever. So while we are slightly below last year, it's still very solid. We're still seeing rate growth in our street rates. For the quarter, we grew 6% to 7%, and we continue to push those here into the fourth quarter.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any color on concessions to get people and then what -- how that's changed as a percentage of revenue in absolute dollar terms?
componenttext: And any color on concessions to get people and then what -- how that's changed as a percentage of revenue in absolute dollar terms?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our discounts are up slightly from where they were. Last year was the kind of bottom where you -- as a percentage of revenues, if you take discounts divided by revenues, they were around 3%. Current year, they've ticked up slightly from there, but
componenttext: Yes. So our discounts are up slightly from where they were. Last year was the kind of bottom where you -- as a percentage of revenues, if you take discounts divided by revenues, they were around 3%. Current year, they've ticked up slightly from there, but they're going to tick up for a couple of things. One is the fact that our rates are up; and then the second thing that affects discounts, obviously, is how many rentals you're during that month. With rentals being down slightly, that helps. With rates being up, that hurts. And then in addition, we are offering slightly more discounts right now to try to compensate a little bit for our drop in occupancy. We entered a quarter about 40 basis points below where we were last year, we would like to pick up a little bit of that going into slow season here.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz from UBS.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones. In terms of the joint venture acquisitions, can you talk about what prompted these? Is this driven by your partners coming to you and saying they wanted to sell? Any insight into why now? And then did you have a ROFO on those?
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones. In terms of the joint venture acquisitions, can you talk about what prompted these? Is this driven by your partners coming to you and saying they wanted to sell? Any insight into why now? And then did you have a ROFO on those?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll answer the second piece. We have a ROFO in all of our joint ventures, but that was not the triggering factor here. We've done 5 transactions with 4 different joint ventures, all managed by Prudential. Each venture is run by a different portfolio m
componenttext: So I'll answer the second piece. We have a ROFO in all of our joint ventures, but that was not the triggering factor here. We've done 5 transactions with 4 different joint ventures, all managed by Prudential. Each venture is run by a different portfolio manager, has a different strategy, and the catalyst for the transaction in each case was different. In some case, we had an unsolicited offer for a property that we didn't want to sell. That started the discussion. In another case, the portfolio manager wanted to change up his geographical diversification and wanted to sell a bunch of properties, primarily in California. From our standpoint though, the similarity in each venture was that we had an embedded promote in the venture that we could not get to without any capital transaction. So we restructured -- earlier this year, we restructured 2 of the accounts without a capital transaction and realized over $40 million in promote. And then in the purchases we've done from the 2 single client accounts, the sales proceeds to the venture would be sufficient to satisfy the accrued preferred return, pay down some capital and put us in a position going forward where we will be cash flow promoted in the ventures.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that color. And then I just had one -- second one on supply. Just any changes in the supply picture in terms of expected starts out there, any new markets where you're seeing it start to get more heated than maybe you initially thought?
componenttext: Appreciate that color. And then I just had one -- second one on supply. Just any changes in the supply picture in terms of expected starts out there, any new markets where you're seeing it start to get more heated than maybe you initially thought?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the picture looks pretty much the same to us. We see increasing supply from a period where there was very little supply. The market that we see supply are the markets that have limited barriers to entry, primarily. Many markets in California and o
componenttext: I think the picture looks pretty much the same to us. We see increasing supply from a period where there was very little supply. The market that we see supply are the markets that have limited barriers to entry, primarily. Many markets in California and others don't -- we don't see that supply. Maybe a new market we're starting to focus on will be Austin, Texas. [ph] But overall, supply -- we are in the development cycle. We're seeing increased supply. We're seeing, in some instances, it affects our operations. In some instances, it doesn't. But it -- we -- on a portfolio level, we still perceive it to be at a manageable, moderate level.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeremy, I would maybe add one thing to that. And that is, clearly, as these properties open, there's demand. If you look in our supplementals and look at the occupancy of our CofO deals, these properties are leasing up extremely quickly. So obviously, the
componenttext: Jeremy, I would maybe add one thing to that. And that is, clearly, as these properties open, there's demand. If you look in our supplementals and look at the occupancy of our CofO deals, these properties are leasing up extremely quickly. So obviously, there's some type of pent-up demand.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: By the way, Jeremy, it's Spencer. One of the things you need to know is just because a macro market might have a lot of supply doesn't necessarily mean that it's going to impact certain individual sites. A lot of noise has been made about South Florida an
componenttext: By the way, Jeremy, it's Spencer. One of the things you need to know is just because a macro market might have a lot of supply doesn't necessarily mean that it's going to impact certain individual sites. A lot of noise has been made about South Florida and Miami. Well, this past quarter, our revenues were up 6.8% and NOI was up 7.3%. So there can be new supply in Miami but, apparently, today it's not having any impact that's discernible on our property level performance because those sites aren't within a 3- or 4- or 5-mile radius of our current operations. So it all depends, as you look across the country, just what [ph] the impact of supply.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay from RBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay from RBC.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It looks like street rates are still pretty healthy, renewal rates are pretty good, concessions are slightly higher and occupancy is just a tad lower than you'd expect, but we're seeing about 150 basis points sequential decline in revenue growth for likel
componenttext: It looks like street rates are still pretty healthy, renewal rates are pretty good, concessions are slightly higher and occupancy is just a tad lower than you'd expect, but we're seeing about 150 basis points sequential decline in revenue growth for likely 3 quarters in a row potentially to get to the low end of guidance. What is going on? Is it just you guys are above market and you just resetting back to a more normal level, is that the driver? Or is it the concessions? What is driving the 150 bps a quarter?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So year-to-date, we've had 150 bps per quarter. So Q1 to Q2, Q2 to Q3, it's been 150 bps per quarter. That's coming off of all-time highs, record NOI growth. I would tell you the rate of decline has slowed from the second going into the third quarter
componenttext: Yes. So year-to-date, we've had 150 bps per quarter. So Q1 to Q2, Q2 to Q3, it's been 150 bps per quarter. That's coming off of all-time highs, record NOI growth. I would tell you the rate of decline has slowed from the second going into the third quarter. So it was fairly steep and then later, in the third quarter, it has absolutely slowed.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So would it be potentially you guys are just above market for -- even though new lease grows [ph] or effective rent was growing or street rate was growing, call it, 5%, you guys might have been above. And as your portfolio starts to reset back to wh
componenttext: Okay. So would it be potentially you guys are just above market for -- even though new lease grows [ph] or effective rent was growing or street rate was growing, call it, 5%, you guys might have been above. And as your portfolio starts to reset back to where the market is, the pace of decline will start to moderate and maybe start to reaccelerate again. Is that how should we should look at it?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you it's tough by market because every market is a little bit different. Some markets, it truly is new supply. Other markets, it's that we have grown 15% for 2 years in a row. We wouldn't expect to grow 15% again next year. So Denver is a com
componenttext: I would tell you it's tough by market because every market is a little bit different. Some markets, it truly is new supply. Other markets, it's that we have grown 15% for 2 years in a row. We wouldn't expect to grow 15% again next year. So Denver is a combination of supply. Plus, Denver in 2014 grew double digits; 2015, double digits; 2016, it's now, in this quarter, went slightly negative. So it varies by market. But overall, you're coming off of record highs. It's just the timing of when you're coming off of those.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as I recall you guys do have some governors that you don't [ph] want to be too far above market. It sounds like [ph] you guys might have been somewhere where the governors were at and then you had the new supply. And that's why we're seeing
componenttext: Okay. And then as I recall you guys do have some governors that you don't [ph] want to be too far above market. It sounds like [ph] you guys might have been somewhere where the governors were at and then you had the new supply. And that's why we're seeing such a drastic decline in Denver, and that will probably be the most extreme example. Is that a fair assessment?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's probably fair. The one thing we do have, like you mentioned, is the governor. So what governs that is street rates. So as street rates are increasing, you do have the ability to increase existing customers also. But if street rates aren't m
componenttext: I think that's probably fair. The one thing we do have, like you mentioned, is the governor. So what governs that is street rates. So as street rates are increasing, you do have the ability to increase existing customers also. But if street rates aren't moving, then your existing customers won't be getting rate increases at some point also.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, just on the -- there's a lot of new supply and we [ph] always talked about how it affected your current operations. But what do you see as far as the managed business or maybe your CofO business? How -- I guess, how much share of th
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, just on the -- there's a lot of new supply and we [ph] always talked about how it affected your current operations. But what do you see as far as the managed business or maybe your CofO business? How -- I guess, how much share of the new development can you take in your market, either developers wanting to affiliate with Extra Space. I [ph] see some developments in Charlotte that will be managed by you. I just wondered how much opportunity it is for you.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thank you very much for asking that question because we always talk about development as a risk draw [ph] business. Well, development also provides an opportunity for us. If you look at our supplements and see how our CofO assets are leasing up, you ca
componenttext: So thank you very much for asking that question because we always talk about development as a risk draw [ph] business. Well, development also provides an opportunity for us. If you look at our supplements and see how our CofO assets are leasing up, you can get an idea of what good investments those are going to be and the value those are going to add to our shareholders. And also on the managed side, as you point out, the vast, vast majority of our incoming -- our pipeline of managed stores are new developments. So we will be able to grow the platform. We aren't growing it this year even though we had some sales out of the management plus [ph] platform and be able to continue to grow that business, both as a revenue generator, a source of additional data and a pipeline for future acquisitions.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose from Citigroup.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just ask if you're seeing any changes in seller expectations because [ph] despite very healthy fundamentals, still the pace, obviously, has declined. And just wondering if you're -- and if you've changed your underwriting at all, given a littl
componenttext: I wanted to just ask if you're seeing any changes in seller expectations because [ph] despite very healthy fundamentals, still the pace, obviously, has declined. And just wondering if you're -- and if you've changed your underwriting at all, given a little bit of slowdown at the industry? Or are you seeing any kind of change in private market cap rates?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, sellers always have unrealistic expectations, and I think they still have unrealistic expectations. But to the point of your question, we feel that the cap rate compression has stopped and that things are still trading at very healthy prices but, pe
componenttext: Well, sellers always have unrealistic expectations, and I think they still have unrealistic expectations. But to the point of your question, we feel that the cap rate compression has stopped and that things are still trading at very healthy prices but, perhaps, there's fewer bidders and there's not as much pressure on pricing. We -- I think through this period, we have done a good job of being realistic and disciplined in our underwriting. And because of that, we have not been successful with widely marketed deals. Only about 12% of the deals we have approved this year in our real estate community were from a broker. Everything else came through some type of relationship or off-market transaction. So we have not changed our underwriting, we continue to try to be disciplined and I think we're going to continue to be largely unsuccessful in the bid auction market until there's a significant change.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just switching to the CofO deals for a second, have you seen any sort of change in the frequency of folks approaching you with these kinds of deals, say, versus 6 months ago?
componenttext: Okay. And just switching to the CofO deals for a second, have you seen any sort of change in the frequency of folks approaching you with these kinds of deals, say, versus 6 months ago?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't -- I think we've always had a very strong pipeline of CofO deals, and we see -- storage is still a very, very healthy business and folks who have not been in storage before want to get into storage and want to be developers and approach us in a
componenttext: I wouldn't -- I think we've always had a very strong pipeline of CofO deals, and we see -- storage is still a very, very healthy business and folks who have not been in storage before want to get into storage and want to be developers and approach us in a pretty consistent basis. So I think the pipeline is still strong. And we're very selective, both in terms of who we want the developers to be and which projects we want to commit to in terms of what else is being developed in that area.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And Spencer, I wanted to add on my best wishes to you as well going forward.
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And Spencer, I wanted to add on my best wishes to you as well going forward.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Smedes.
componenttext: Thank you very much, Smedes.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund from Jefferies.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first off, Spencer, just enjoy your retirement. It's been a pleasure working with you.
componenttext: Yes, first off, Spencer, just enjoy your retirement. It's been a pleasure working with you.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: My pleasure, [ph] George, thank you.
componenttext: My pleasure, [ph] George, thank you.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess my 2 questions have to do with 2 specific markets. I guess one in New York, if you can just comment a bit on the performance, on the sequential slowdown in revenue growth. And then also in Denver, sort of what drove that large increase in same
componenttext: And I guess my 2 questions have to do with 2 specific markets. I guess one in New York, if you can just comment a bit on the performance, on the sequential slowdown in revenue growth. And then also in Denver, sort of what drove that large increase in same-store expenses, up 25%?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the Denver one first and then maybe, Joe, you want to take New York? The Denver one is actually a property tax increase in expenses. And it's not that the taxes this year went up, it's a comp from last year where we won an appeal last year, and
componenttext: I'll take the Denver one first and then maybe, Joe, you want to take New York? The Denver one is actually a property tax increase in expenses. And it's not that the taxes this year went up, it's a comp from last year where we won an appeal last year, and so you had expenses go down because we got effectively a lower rate or a cash-back. So it's really more of a year-over-year comparison on the expense side than a big increase in expenses.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: New York is a little bit of a mystery to us. It's a good market. There's some development coming online. The saturation is extremely low. Perhaps, it's a market where Valey [ph] is making a little bit of an inroad, but we have a hard time understanding an
componenttext: New York is a little bit of a mystery to us. It's a good market. There's some development coming online. The saturation is extremely low. Perhaps, it's a market where Valey [ph] is making a little bit of an inroad, but we have a hard time understanding and predicting the New York market right now.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas from KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas from KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Spencer, best of luck in retirement. Good luck. First question, Joe or Scott maybe, just following up on the discounting. Can you just talk a little bit more about the discounting in the quarter, maybe quantify what percent of customers receive discounts
componenttext: Spencer, best of luck in retirement. Good luck. First question, Joe or Scott maybe, just following up on the discounting. Can you just talk a little bit more about the discounting in the quarter, maybe quantify what percent of customers receive discounts in the quarter, how that compared year-over-year?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So year-over-year, current year, about 58% of our new customers received a discount compared to last year, it was 47% of our new customers. Now that can be a little misleading sometimes because it's going to depend on which discount they receive. So
componenttext: Yes. So year-over-year, current year, about 58% of our new customers received a discount compared to last year, it was 47% of our new customers. Now that can be a little misleading sometimes because it's going to depend on which discount they receive. So even though fewer customers last year received a discount, it's possible you could have given more discounts if you gave a larger discount. But that is -- we're still -- majority of our customers coming in the door are getting the discount as they come in.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So how should we think about that discounting in the context of the 7% higher asking rents that were mentioned year-over-year? I mean, what does that mean for move-in rates in the quarter on a year-over-year basis?
componenttext: Okay. So how should we think about that discounting in the context of the 7% higher asking rents that were mentioned year-over-year? I mean, what does that mean for move-in rates in the quarter on a year-over-year basis?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So discounts, assuming all things were equal, a 7% increase in asking rates would be a 7% increase in discounts. I would tell you, they're slightly higher than that because we have increased the percentage of customers getting the discount. And then we've
componenttext: So discounts, assuming all things were equal, a 7% increase in asking rates would be a 7% increase in discounts. I would tell you, they're slightly higher than that because we have increased the percentage of customers getting the discount. And then we've also -- depending on the market, depending on occupancy, we'll continue to change discounts offered, the specific discount offered. But it's not significantly higher, but it is higher and it is affecting your net rental income.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just maybe for Joe, just like a bigger picture question here, just sticking with revenue growth and the deceleration that we're seeing today. Realizing we're coming off record highs, are there any signs of stabilization today, whether it is
componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe for Joe, just like a bigger picture question here, just sticking with revenue growth and the deceleration that we're seeing today. Realizing we're coming off record highs, are there any signs of stabilization today, whether it is discounting or something else though that you might be able to point to? Or do you think that this deceleration on a broader portfolio level could continue over the next several quarters?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our view is that deceleration is going to moderate and flatten out, and we are going to revert to more normal rates of growth, self storage normal [ph] which historically has been higher than other property types. So we're already feeling that, and that's
componenttext: Our view is that deceleration is going to moderate and flatten out, and we are going to revert to more normal rates of growth, self storage normal [ph] which historically has been higher than other property types. So we're already feeling that, and that's what we expect.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it seems like your comments suggest then that you think that you would just sort of moderate and sort of stair step down to a level that stabilizes in the coming quarters then?
componenttext: Okay. So it seems like your comments suggest then that you think that you would just sort of moderate and sort of stair step down to a level that stabilizes in the coming quarters then?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe if we could start off with maybe you can provide some October stats on street rate growth and promotions?
componenttext: So maybe if we could start off with maybe you can provide some October stats on street rate growth and promotions?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our street rate growth for October is slightly lower than where it was in the third quarter. So you are mid-5s in street rate growth, mid- to upper 5s depending on kind of the time. Discounts are pretty similar to what they were in the third quarter,
componenttext: Yes. Our street rate growth for October is slightly lower than where it was in the third quarter. So you are mid-5s in street rate growth, mid- to upper 5s depending on kind of the time. Discounts are pretty similar to what they were in the third quarter, up slightly, but -- the reason we're adjusting discounts and pricing is obviously to try to recoup some of the occupancy that were down.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So if I look at your guidance, the adjusted guidance and what it implies for the fourth quarter, we're roughly looking at like a low 5% seems [ph] revenue growth rate. What's interesting about that is that, probably, that your rent per occupied squ
componenttext: Right. So if I look at your guidance, the adjusted guidance and what it implies for the fourth quarter, we're roughly looking at like a low 5% seems [ph] revenue growth rate. What's interesting about that is that, probably, that your rent per occupied square foot growth rate for the first time is going to surpass same-store revenue growth rate, at least it's trending that way. So it feels like there may be some levers, whether that's promotions like we talked about or existing customer rate increases having a lower benefit to the same-store revenue numbers or just decrease in street rates. But it feels like there are some other levers that are giving way, so I was wondering if you had any thoughts on that.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you in terms of the levers, the majority of our growth at the end of last year and all of this year has been street rate growth. Existing customer rate increases don't add a lot, but it is almost entirely rate growth. That has been offse
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you in terms of the levers, the majority of our growth at the end of last year and all of this year has been street rate growth. Existing customer rate increases don't add a lot, but it is almost entirely rate growth. That has been offset slightly by discounts, and bad debt has increased nominally [ph] also.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess in the same line of questioning, I know [ph] tend to focus a lot on the supply issues, but maybe just something on the demand side because it feels like even your good markets are not just -- not as much as L.A. but just overall, some of
componenttext: Okay. And I guess in the same line of questioning, I know [ph] tend to focus a lot on the supply issues, but maybe just something on the demand side because it feels like even your good markets are not just -- not as much as L.A. but just overall, some of the great markets are becoming just very good and just kind of toning down a notch. Is there something that you can point to on the demand side? Are customers shopping [ph] price more often? Or is there just less traffic? Or are there some things that you're seeing out there that is pointing towards just a little bit weaker demand than what we're used to?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing is just the cyclicality of markets. If you -- we did a study, we looked at almost 90 markets over a 10-year period, and one thing you see is that markets are strong and then markets are less strong and they're not correlated and
componenttext: I think what we're seeing is just the cyclicality of markets. If you -- we did a study, we looked at almost 90 markets over a 10-year period, and one thing you see is that markets are strong and then markets are less strong and they're not correlated and they move in all different directions. Our #1 market for 10-year NOI growth is Chicago, which is now one of our weaker markets. So we fully expect to see markets like Sacramento be very strong for a few years and then perhaps be not as strong. One of our markets now that we reported as a weaker market is Boston. Boston is not a market that's been impacted by a lot of supply, but it's just kind of in that cyclical pattern that we see. So we're very happy to have designed a portfolio that is highly, highly diversified across many, many markets that will smooth out the ups and downs of individual markets.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats, Spencer, on retirement. And Joe, [ph] congrats on your new role. Two quick questions, just on the comments about steady state, can you give us some context? If I look at like the last 10 years, self storage same-store NOI is probably in the 4% t
componenttext: Congrats, Spencer, on retirement. And Joe, [ph] congrats on your new role. Two quick questions, just on the comments about steady state, can you give us some context? If I look at like the last 10 years, self storage same-store NOI is probably in the 4% to 5% same-store NOI range. And I'm just trying to understand like you say steady-state, given sort of all the changes in technology, et cetera, is that somewhere in between the long-term average and today's numbers? Is it -- can you just give us some sense of what steady state means?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you, we're reverting back to that historical average of 4% to 5%. I think as a company, you're going to have times that's above that, They're not going to be way above, and there's times you're going to be below that and they're not going to
componenttext: I would tell you, we're reverting back to that historical average of 4% to 5%. I think as a company, you're going to have times that's above that, They're not going to be way above, and there's times you're going to be below that and they're not going to be way below. That is that beauty of self-storage is a fairly stable property type.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Supply and talking to some operators, it seems like in markets where there was this uptick in supply, given their performance -- subsequent performance, it seems like some projects are getting either pushed out or delayed and it's also just taking longer
componenttext: Supply and talking to some operators, it seems like in markets where there was this uptick in supply, given their performance -- subsequent performance, it seems like some projects are getting either pushed out or delayed and it's also just taking longer to get new projects started, just given the capacity issues in terms of contractors. I'm just wondering if you've seen that in any market?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We see that across all markets, that a fairly sizable percentage of planned projects do not get built because of local opposition, increasing construction costs, difficulty getting financing, land cost, whatever it is. But that being said, there are proje
componenttext: We see that across all markets, that a fairly sizable percentage of planned projects do not get built because of local opposition, increasing construction costs, difficulty getting financing, land cost, whatever it is. But that being said, there are projects being added to the funnel, and a good portion of them get -- don't make it to the funnel, but there are still more projects getting added to the funnel. So I think the factors you talked about, it will slow and moderate the development cycle but not stop it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gaurav Mehta from Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gaurav Mehta from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick ones. Number one, for your existing customers, have you seen any pushback from your tenants on rent increases? And can you comment on percentage of move out for rent increases in your portfolio?
componenttext: A couple of quick ones. Number one, for your existing customers, have you seen any pushback from your tenants on rent increases? And can you comment on percentage of move out for rent increases in your portfolio?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have not seen any changes, if that's the question. We still have a very small percentage of customers who will actually go get their boxes and move out when they get the rate increase. We continue to -- every time we send out a rent increase, keep a
componenttext: So we have not seen any changes, if that's the question. We still have a very small percentage of customers who will actually go get their boxes and move out when they get the rate increase. We continue to -- every time we send out a rent increase, keep a control group and measure the control groups move out rate against the folks who got the rate increase. I think about 1% of the people move out, so there's been no change in that. It's something we continue to monitor, and it proves to us that the rate increase program continues to be valuable.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and the second, you talked about discounts -- higher discounts in the quarter. Were there any markets where you had to use more discount than others?
componenttext: Okay, and the second, you talked about discounts -- higher discounts in the quarter. Were there any markets where you had to use more discount than others?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any market that is shown softness in terms of occupancy or rate, we will typically increase the discounts. As we look at the leverage we have to pool, you're going to look first to increase your spend on the web. The last thing that you want to do is decr
componenttext: Any market that is shown softness in terms of occupancy or rate, we will typically increase the discounts. As we look at the leverage we have to pool, you're going to look first to increase your spend on the web. The last thing that you want to do is decrease your rate. So in terms of magnitude, you'll increase your spend on the web. You will increase your discount or change your rate. That you typically want to do that in that order because of the cost for the long-term costs or benefit.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question from the line of Gwen Clark from Evercore ISI.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an update of how you're thinking about the threat to the industry and also some color on [indiscernible] per square foot?
componenttext: Can you give us an update of how you're thinking about the threat to the industry and also some color on [indiscernible] per square foot?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've done quite a bit of research on the valley storage, and we don't see it as an imminent threat. We understand it a lot. We've done deliveries with companies. We have done click-throughs to see if they choose them over us. And right now, based on
componenttext: Yes, we've done quite a bit of research on the valley storage, and we don't see it as an imminent threat. We understand it a lot. We've done deliveries with companies. We have done click-throughs to see if they choose them over us. And right now, based on the way it's priced, we do not see it as a major threat. The only thing that we have is the ability to get into that business fairly quickly. We have the real estate, we have the customer list. So not a huge threat at this time.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And on a different note, it looks like Denver was one of the first markets to go negative. Can you give us an update on how to think about what markets could be next and what would be driving that?

componenttext: It's tough to predict the future. If you look at a market that has had 15% growth 2 years in a row and had a lot of new supply, I think that is probable that, that market is not going to be great next year [indiscernible].

componenttext: Scott, I appreciate the comment in regards to not focusing necessarily on what your share price is today in terms of driving your gross strategy. But what is it to the team looks for that would -- or that will tell you that it's time to slow -- slow growth from that perspective?

componenttext: I would tell you when things are not accretive anymore. So in other words, what you're paying for property is greater than your cost of capital. So we're very careful in terms of assessing our cost of equity and assessing the cost of debt. And trying to look at that long term and having realistic growth assumptions. But I think that's what can cause you bigger problems, pricing stays extremely low.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and you obviously seen great success on producing double-digit FFO growth over many consecutive quarters now. Do you consider that a hard target internally as you're looking at acquisitions? Or is that just an outcome of what you -- what the strateg
componenttext: Okay, and you obviously seen great success on producing double-digit FFO growth over many consecutive quarters now. Do you consider that a hard target internally as you're looking at acquisitions? Or is that just an outcome of what you -- what the strategy that you've employed, and you're okay with not producing double-digit FFO growth at a certain point in time?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we are not okay with not producing -- that's too many negatives. Our goal -- we are very focused on producing double-digit FFO growth, both through acquisition and all the other levers we have to pull that are -- to do that. What it adds as we talked
componenttext: No, we are not okay with not producing -- that's too many negatives. Our goal -- we are very focused on producing double-digit FFO growth, both through acquisition and all the other levers we have to pull that are -- to do that. What it adds as we talked about restructuring our ventures, our management plus platform. We will add over 9,000 units this year through expansions or where we've turned 10 by 10 to [ph] 5 by 5. So we are very focused on that goal.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your cost of capital and how you're deploying capital at this point in the cycle. Can you talk about the 3 buckets that you invested in, the JV assets, that sounds like they're pretty mature. I think you acquired 3 properties outside of that in the quarte
componenttext: Your cost of capital and how you're deploying capital at this point in the cycle. Can you talk about the 3 buckets that you invested in, the JV assets, that sounds like they're pretty mature. I think you acquired 3 properties outside of that in the quarter and then your CofO deals. Is there a way to quantify your turn expectations side by side with those 3?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the questions on one [ph]. I think I'd tell you we're very focused on the long-term cost of capital. Debt as well as equity and it's going to be the mix of debt and equity. In terms of returns, we're typically a cap rate buyer. We also consider your
componenttext: Well, the questions on one [ph]. I think I'd tell you we're very focused on the long-term cost of capital. Debt as well as equity and it's going to be the mix of debt and equity. In terms of returns, we're typically a cap rate buyer. We also consider your replacement costs, we also look at IRRs and we also look at cash on cash yields. Because we are long-term holder, I think cash on cash is probably the most relevant one we focused on rather than just looking at the cap rate today or stabilized cap rates, what's the return because that equalizes -- if you look at a 7-year cash-on-cash return on CofO deal, you now can compare that to how is that cash on cash doing acquisition? I would tell your focus on long-term cost of capital, we'll focus on cash on and cash yields.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just only thing to add, if you look at those 3 types of acquisition, they all serve a different purpose,, right? The assets we buy from a joint venture partner that we managed, we've already maximize performance, there's less upside in those assets. But t
componenttext: Just only thing to add, if you look at those 3 types of acquisition, they all serve a different purpose,, right? The assets we buy from a joint venture partner that we managed, we've already maximize performance, there's less upside in those assets. But there's also less risk. We know that inside and out, we know exactly what the performance is, there's already branded. So those are kind of our safest, lowest returning assets. The CofO deals, we're taking full lease up risk, construction risk and we have the period of dilution that Scott mentioned, those are higher returning type deals in return for taking that lease-up risk. And then the deals you buy on market, they span the globe. There's deals -- our first year cap rate on acquired deals range from 2.7% to 8% [ph]. So that just tells you how much juice there is a lease up value is in the deals. So this could be anywhere along the spectrum.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what are you guys expecting? What's the cash on cash return for the Pru assets because it looks like we do see some are JV assets being pulled into Q4? What's the kind of return expectations there?

componenttext: So the deal we just announced with 2 [ph] where we dissolved that joint venture and purchased 23 assets, the 4 or 12 [ph] cap rate on that was a 5 8. So that gives you a sense of that.

componenttext: So I would tell you, from property tax perspective, it would be above inflation. I mean, the last couple of years we've seen 4% to 6%. We expect that again next year. We hope to be able to grow less than inflation in some of the other areas by some of the things we're doing. So hopefully, that will offset some of it. But in terms of marketing, hopefully as we grow, we will certainly experience of the size and scale benefit. But it will help to keep that somewhere in the inflationary.

componenttext: I think there's some confusion about what a normalized growth means for the sector and for Extra Space. Can you try to quantify it a bit more specifically?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so there are a lot of numbers out there, Gwen. It's Spencer. And if you look back over the last 10-plus years, it's hard to get an exact read on this because you got some occupancy gains and other things mixed in there. But some numbers I've used in
componenttext: Yes, so there are a lot of numbers out there, Gwen. It's Spencer. And if you look back over the last 10-plus years, it's hard to get an exact read on this because you got some occupancy gains and other things mixed in there. But some numbers I've used in the past for the 10-year average for the storage sector, operators specifically, the NOI growth has been about 5.3%. That's a very healthy report card in the word of REITs by any measure. Extra Space has done a little bit better than that. We have averaged about 6.7% over that 10-plus year period and the last quarter we just reported was 7.8%. We're still way above the historical norm, and you can pull out some of occupancy and other things that might be inflating some of those numbers, but my personal opinion is not only today but going forward, storage will be amongst the best, if not the best performing asset class. So yes, we've seen some deceleration. I'm personally a little surprised at the negativity, but I have a high degree of confidence that storage and Extra Space, in particular, are going to put up excellent results by any measure in the world of REITs. And I don't think any of that changes. So reverting to maybe more normal historical trends, it's still impressive.
