componenttextpreview: First off, congratulations, Spencer. It's been great working with you. So congratulations on your retirement.
componenttext: First off, congratulations, Spencer. It's been great working with you. So congratulations on your retirement.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I had a question in terms of the acquisitions and sort of plans for long-term funding. Obviously, a lot more acquisitions this quarter and for the year -- more than planned. But given where the stock price is trading, curious what your plans are fo
componenttext: Scott, I had a question in terms of the acquisitions and sort of plans for long-term funding. Obviously, a lot more acquisitions this quarter and for the year -- more than planned. But given where the stock price is trading, curious what your plans are for funding those acquisitions and if you'd be comfortable raising equity at the current price.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, I would tell you that we don't look at our current stock price anytime we make an acquisition decision. It's not made with a short-term cost of capital in mind. We always look at the long-term cost. So we've always tried to have many so
componenttext: Yes, first of all, I would tell you that we don't look at our current stock price anytime we make an acquisition decision. It's not made with a short-term cost of capital in mind. We always look at the long-term cost. So we've always tried to have many sources of capital. And right now, I would tell you that we still do. Debt is an option. We just closed this facility and it gives us a fair amount of capacity. The preferred market's still very good. And our stock price, we don't like it as much today as we have in the past, but I think that we'll always look to access the cheapest cost of capital which could also include joint ventures or even proceeds from the sales of properties.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So would you be willing to increase debt levels for the short term until maybe you have a better stock price?
componenttext: So would you be willing to increase debt levels for the short term until maybe you have a better stock price?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marginally, yes, we would.
componenttext: Marginally, yes, we would.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Juan Sanabria from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Juan Sanabria from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just hoping you could talk a little bit about the state of demand. If I look at Page 20 of your supplemental, it looks like rentable square feet on a same-store basis declined year-over-year for the 3 months and for the 9 months, and you kind of tal
componenttext: I was just hoping you could talk a little bit about the state of demand. If I look at Page 20 of your supplemental, it looks like rentable square feet on a same-store basis declined year-over-year for the 3 months and for the 9 months, and you kind of talked about concessions going up. So just curious about the health of demand and kind of what you're having to offer to get people to sign the leases.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm assuming you're looking at the rentals and vacates in our supplementals. The first thing I'd --
componenttext: Yes. I'm assuming you're looking at the rentals and vacates in our supplementals. The first thing I'd --

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We always tell people to be careful with looking at rentals and vacates. It depends a little bit on what happened last year. We focus more on occupancy and revenue growth. I would tell you demand is still solid. We are very near our record high occupancy
componenttext: We always tell people to be careful with looking at rentals and vacates. It depends a little bit on what happened last year. We focus more on occupancy and revenue growth. I would tell you demand is still solid. We are very near our record high occupancy for this time of year. Last year was our best year ever. So while we are slightly below last year, it's still very solid. We're still seeing rate growth in our street rates. For the quarter, we grew 6% to 7%, and we continue to push those here into the fourth quarter.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any color on concessions to get people in and what -- how that's changed as a percentage of revenue in absolute dollar terms?
componenttext: And any color on concessions to get people in and what -- how that's changed as a percentage of revenue in absolute dollar terms?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our discounts are up slightly from where they were. Last year was the kind of bottom where you -- as a percentage of revenues, if you take discounts divided by revenues, you were around 3%. Current year, they've ticked up slightly from there, but
componenttext: Yes. So our discounts are up slightly from where they were. Last year was the kind of bottom where you -- as a percentage of revenues, if you take discounts divided by revenues, you were around 3%. Current year, they've ticked up slightly from there, but they're going to tick up for a couple of things. One is the fact our rates are up; and then the second thing that affects discounts, obviously, is how many rentals you're during that month. With rentals being down slightly, that helps. With rates being up, that hurts. And then in addition, we are offering slightly more discounts right now to try to compensate a little bit for our drop in occupancy. We entered the quarter about 40 basis points below where we were last year. We would like to pick up a little bit of that going into the slow season here.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz from UBS.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones. In terms of the joint venture acquisitions, can you talk about what prompted these? Is this driven by your partners coming to you and saying they wanted to sell? Any insight into why now? And then did you have a ROFO on those?
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones. In terms of the joint venture acquisitions, can you talk about what prompted these? Is this driven by your partners coming to you and saying they wanted to sell? Any insight into why now? And then did you have a ROFO on those?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll answer the second piece. We have a ROFO in all of our joint ventures, but that was not the triggering factor here. We've done 5 transactions with 4 different joint ventures, all managed by Prudential. Each venture is run by a different portfolio m
componenttext: So I'll answer the second piece. We have a ROFO in all of our joint ventures, but that was not the triggering factor here. We've done 5 transactions with 4 different joint ventures, all managed by Prudential. Each venture is run by a different portfolio manager, has a different strategy, and the catalyst for the transaction in each case was different. In some case, we had an unsolicited offer for a property that we didn't want to sell. That started the discussion. In another case, the portfolio manager wanted to change up his geographical diversification and wanted to sell a bunch of properties, primarily in California. From our standpoint though, the similarity in each venture was that we had an embedded promote in the venture that we could not get to without a capital transaction. So we restructured -- earlier this year, we restructured 2 of the accounts without a capital transaction and realized over $40 million in promote. And then in the purchases we've done from the 2 single client accounts, the sales proceeds to the venture will be sufficient to satisfy the accrued preferred return, pay down some capital and put us in a position going forward where we will be cash flow promoted in the ventures.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that color. And then I just had one -- second one on supply. Just any changes in the supply picture in terms of expected starts out there? Any new markets where you're seeing it start to get more heated than maybe you initially thought?
componenttext: Appreciate that color. And then I just had one -- second one on supply. Just any changes in the supply picture in terms of expected starts out there? Any new markets where you're seeing it start to get more heated than maybe you initially thought?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the picture looks pretty much the same to us. We see increasing supply from a period where there was very little supply. The market that we see supply are the markets that have limited barriers to entry, primarily. Many markets in California and o
componenttext: I think the picture looks pretty much the same to us. We see increasing supply from a period where there was very little supply. The market that we see supply are the markets that have limited barriers to entry, primarily. Many markets in California and others don't -- we don't see that supply. Maybe a new market we're starting to focus on would be Austin, Texas. But overall, supply -- we are in the development cycle. We're seeing increased supply. We're seeing, in some instances, it affects our operations. In some instances, it doesn't. But it -- we -- on a portfolio level, we still perceive it to be at a manageable, moderate level.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeremy, I would maybe add one thing to that. And that is, clearly, as these properties open, there's demand. If you look in our supplementals and look at the occupancy of our CofO deals, these properties are leasing up extremely quickly. So obviously, the
componenttext: Jeremy, I would maybe add one thing to that. And that is, clearly, as these properties open, there's demand. If you look in our supplementals and look at the occupancy of our CofO deals, these properties are leasing up extremely quickly. So obviously, there's some type of pent-up demand.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: By the way, Jeremy, it's Spencer. One of the things you need to know is just because a macro market might have a lot of supply doesn't necessarily mean that it's going to impact certain individual sites. A lot of noise has been made about South Florida an
componenttext: By the way, Jeremy, it's Spencer. One of the things you need to know is just because a macro market might have a lot of supply doesn't necessarily mean that it's going to impact certain individual sites. A lot of noise has been made about South Florida and Miami. Well, this past quarter, our revenues were up 6.8% and NOI was up 7.3%. So there can be new supply in Miami but, apparently, today it's not having any impact that's discernible on our property level performance because those sites aren't within a 3- or 4- or 5-mile radius of our current operations. So it all depends, as you look across the country, the city impact of supply.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay from RBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay from RBC.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It looks like street rates are still pretty healthy, renewal rates are pretty good, concessions are slightly higher and occupancy is just a tad lower than you'd expect, but we're seeing about 150 basis points sequential decline in revenue growth for likel
componenttext: It looks like street rates are still pretty healthy, renewal rates are pretty good, concessions are slightly higher and occupancy is just a tad lower than you'd expect, but we're seeing about 150 basis points sequential decline in revenue growth for likely 3 quarters in a row potentially to get to the low end of guidance. What is going on? Is it just you guys are above market and you're just resetting back to a more normal level, is that the driver? Or is it the concessions? What is driving the 150 bps a quarter?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So year-to-date, we've had 150 bps per quarter. So Q1 to Q2, Q2 to Q3, it's been 150 bps per quarter. That's coming off of all-time highs, record NOI growth. I would tell you the rate of decline has slowed from the second going into the third quarter
componenttext: Yes. So year-to-date, we've had 150 bps per quarter. So Q1 to Q2, Q2 to Q3, it's been 150 bps per quarter. That's coming off of all-time highs, record NOI growth. I would tell you the rate of decline has slowed from the second going into the third quarter. So it was fairly steep and then later, in the third quarter, it has absolutely slowed.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So would it be potentially you guys are just above market for -- even though new lease growth or effective rent was growing or street rate was growing, call it, 5%, you guys might have been above. And as your portfolio starts to reset back to where
componenttext: Okay. So would it be potentially you guys are just above market for -- even though new lease growth or effective rent was growing or street rate was growing, call it, 5%, you guys might have been above. And as your portfolio starts to reset back to where the market is, the pace of decline will start to moderate and maybe start to reaccelerate again. Is that how should we should look at it?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you it's tough by market because every market is a little bit different. Some markets, it truly is new supply. Other markets, it's that we have grown 15% for 2 years in a row. We wouldn't expect to grow 15% again next year. So Denver is a com
componenttext: I would tell you it's tough by market because every market is a little bit different. Some markets, it truly is new supply. Other markets, it's that we have grown 15% for 2 years in a row. We wouldn't expect to grow 15% again next year. So Denver is a combination of supply. Plus, Denver in 2014 grew double digits; 2015, double digits; 2016, it's now, in this quarter, went slightly negative. So it varies by market. But overall, you're coming off of record highs. It's just the timing of when you're coming off of those.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as I recall, you guys do have some governors that you don't want to be too far above market. It sounds like you guys might have been somewhere where the governors were at and then you had the new supply. And that's why we're seeing such a d
componenttext: Okay. And then as I recall, you guys do have some governors that you don't want to be too far above market. It sounds like you guys might have been somewhere where the governors were at and then you had the new supply. And that's why we're seeing such a drastic decline in Denver, and that will probably be the most extreme example. Is that a fair assessment?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's probably fair. The one thing we do have, like you mentioned, is the governor. So what governs that is street rates. So as street rates are increasing, you do have the ability to increase existing customers also. But if street rates aren't m
componenttext: I think that's probably fair. The one thing we do have, like you mentioned, is the governor. So what governs that is street rates. So as street rates are increasing, you do have the ability to increase existing customers also. But if street rates aren't moving, then your existing customers won't be getting rate increases at some point also.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, just on the -- there's a lot of new supply and we always talked about how it will affect your current operations. But what do you see as far as the managed business or maybe your CofO business? How -- I guess, how much share of the
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, just on the -- there's a lot of new supply and we always talked about how it will affect your current operations. But what do you see as far as the managed business or maybe your CofO business? How -- I guess, how much share of the new development can you take in your market, either developers wanting to affiliate with Extra Space. I see some developments in Charlotte that will be managed by you. I just wondered how much opportunity it is for you.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thank you very much for asking that question because we always talk about development as a risk to our business. Well, development also provides an opportunity for us. If you look at our supplements and see how our CofO assets are leasing up, you can g
componenttext: So thank you very much for asking that question because we always talk about development as a risk to our business. Well, development also provides an opportunity for us. If you look at our supplements and see how our CofO assets are leasing up, you can get an idea of what good investments those are going to be and the value those are going to add to our shareholders. And also on the managed side, as you point out, the vast, vast majority of our incoming -- our pipeline of managed stores are new development. So we will be able to grow that platform. We aren't growing it this year even though we had some sales out of the ManagementPlus  platform and be able to continue to grow that business, both as a revenue generator, a source of additional data and a pipeline for future acquisitions.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose from Citigroup.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just ask if you're seeing any changes in seller expectations because despite very healthy fundamentals, still the pace, obviously, has declined. And just wondering if you're -- and if you've changed your underwriting at all, given a little bit
componenttext: I wanted to just ask if you're seeing any changes in seller expectations because despite very healthy fundamentals, still the pace, obviously, has declined. And just wondering if you're -- and if you've changed your underwriting at all, given a little bit of the slowdown of the industry? Or are you seeing any kind of change in private market cap rates?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, sellers always have unrealistic expectations, and I think they still have unrealistic expectations. But to the point of your question, we feel that cap rate compression has stopped and that things are still trading at very healthy prices but, perhap
componenttext: Well, sellers always have unrealistic expectations, and I think they still have unrealistic expectations. But to the point of your question, we feel that cap rate compression has stopped and that things are still trading at very healthy prices but, perhaps, there's fewer bidders and there's not as much pressure on pricing. We -- I think through this period, we have done a good job of being realistic and disciplined in our underwriting. And because of that, we have not been successful with widely-marketed deals. Only about 12% of the deals we have approved this year in our real estate community were from a broker. Everything else came through some type of relationship or off-market transaction. So we have not changed our underwriting, we continue to try to be disciplined and I think we're going to continue to be largely unsuccessful in the bid auction market until there's a significant change.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just switching to the CofO deals for a second, have you seen any sort of change in the frequency of folks approaching you with these kinds of deals, say, versus 6 months ago?
componenttext: Okay. And just switching to the CofO deals for a second, have you seen any sort of change in the frequency of folks approaching you with these kinds of deals, say, versus 6 months ago?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't -- I think we've always had a very strong pipeline of CofO deals, and we see -- storage is still very, very healthy business and folks who have not been in storage before want to get into storage and want to be developers and approach us at a p
componenttext: I wouldn't -- I think we've always had a very strong pipeline of CofO deals, and we see -- storage is still very, very healthy business and folks who have not been in storage before want to get into storage and want to be developers and approach us at a pretty consistent basis. So I think the pipeline is still strong. And we're very selective, both in terms of who we want the developers to be and which projects we want to commit to in terms of what else is being developed in that area.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And Spencer, I wanted to add on my best wishes to you as well going forward.
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And Spencer, I wanted to add on my best wishes to you as well going forward.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Smedes.
componenttext: Thank you very much, Smedes.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund from Jefferies.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first off, Spencer, just enjoy your retirement. It's been a pleasure working with you.
componenttext: Yes, first off, Spencer, just enjoy your retirement. It's been a pleasure working with you.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: My pleasure, George, thank you.
componenttext: My pleasure, George, thank you.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess my 2 questions have to do with 2 specific markets. I guess one in New York, if you can just comment a bit on the performance, on the sequential slowdown in revenue growth. And then also in Denver, sort of what drove that large increase in same
componenttext: And I guess my 2 questions have to do with 2 specific markets. I guess one in New York, if you can just comment a bit on the performance, on the sequential slowdown in revenue growth. And then also in Denver, sort of what drove that large increase in same-store expenses, up 25%?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the Denver one first and then maybe, Joe, you want to take New York? The Denver one is actually a property tax increase in expenses. And it's not that the taxes this year went up, it's a comp from last year where we won an appeal last year, and
componenttext: I'll take the Denver one first and then maybe, Joe, you want to take New York? The Denver one is actually a property tax increase in expenses. And it's not that the taxes this year went up, it's a comp from last year where we won an appeal last year, and so you had expenses go down because we got effectively a lower rate or a cash-back. So it's really more of a year-over-year comparison on the expense side than a big increase in expenses.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: New York is a little bit of a mystery to us. It's a good market. There's some development coming online. The saturation is extremely low. Perhaps, it's a market where valet is making a little bit of an inroad, but we have a hard time understanding and pre
componenttext: New York is a little bit of a mystery to us. It's a good market. There's some development coming online. The saturation is extremely low. Perhaps, it's a market where valet is making a little bit of an inroad, but we have a hard time understanding and predicting the New York market right now.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas from KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas from KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Spencer, best of luck in retirement. Good luck. First question, Joe or Scott maybe, just following up on the discounting. Can you just talk a little bit more about the discounting in the quarter, maybe quantify what percent of customers received discounts
componenttext: Spencer, best of luck in retirement. Good luck. First question, Joe or Scott maybe, just following up on the discounting. Can you just talk a little bit more about the discounting in the quarter, maybe quantify what percent of customers received discounts in the quarter, how that compared year-over-year?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So year-over-year, current year, about 58% of our new customers received a discount compared to last year, it was 47% of our new customers. Now that can be a little misleading sometimes because it's going to depend on which discount they receive. So
componenttext: Yes. So year-over-year, current year, about 58% of our new customers received a discount compared to last year, it was 47% of our new customers. Now that can be a little misleading sometimes because it's going to depend on which discount they receive. So even though fewer customers last year received a discount, it's possible you could have given more discounts if you gave a larger discount. But that is -- we're still -- majority of our customers coming in the door are getting the discount as they come in.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So how should we think about that discounting in the context of the 7% higher asking rents that were mentioned year-over-year? I mean, what does that mean for move-in rates in the quarter on a year-over-year basis?
componenttext: Okay. So how should we think about that discounting in the context of the 7% higher asking rents that were mentioned year-over-year? I mean, what does that mean for move-in rates in the quarter on a year-over-year basis?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So discounts, assuming all things were equal, a 7% increase in asking rates would be a 7% increase in discounts. I would tell you, they are slightly higher than that because we have increased the percentage of customers getting the discount. And then we'v
componenttext: So discounts, assuming all things were equal, a 7% increase in asking rates would be a 7% increase in discounts. I would tell you, they are slightly higher than that because we have increased the percentage of customers getting the discount. And then we've also -- depending on the market, depending on occupancy, we'll continue to change discounts offered, the specific discount offered. But it's not significantly higher, but it is higher and it is affecting your net rental income.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just maybe for Joe, just like a bigger picture question here, just sticking with revenue growth and the deceleration that we're seeing today. Realizing we're coming off record highs, are there any signs of stabilization today, whether it is
componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe for Joe, just like a bigger picture question here, just sticking with revenue growth and the deceleration that we're seeing today. Realizing we're coming off record highs, are there any signs of stabilization today, whether it is discounting or something else though that you might be able to point to? Or do you think that this deceleration on a broader portfolio level could continue over the next several quarters?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our view is that deceleration is going to moderate and flatten out, and we are going to revert to more normal rates of growth, self storage normal which, historically, has been higher than other property types. So we're already feeling that, and that's wh
componenttext: Our view is that deceleration is going to moderate and flatten out, and we are going to revert to more normal rates of growth, self storage normal which, historically, has been higher than other property types. So we're already feeling that, and that's what we expect.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it seems like your comments suggest then that you think that you would just sort of moderate and sort of stair-step down to a level that stabilizes in the coming quarters then?
componenttext: Okay. So it seems like your comments suggest then that you think that you would just sort of moderate and sort of stair-step down to a level that stabilizes in the coming quarters then?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim from SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim from SunTrust.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Spencer, it was great working with you. And best of luck.
componenttext: Spencer, it was great working with you. And best of luck.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Many thanks, Ki Bin.
componenttext: Many thanks, Ki Bin.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe if we could start off with maybe you can provide some October stats on street rate growth and promotions?
componenttext: So maybe if we could start off with maybe you can provide some October stats on street rate growth and promotions?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our street rate growth for October is slightly lower than where it was in the third quarter. So you are mid-5s in street rate growth, mid- to upper 5s depending on kind of the time. Discounts are pretty similar to what they were in the third quarter,
componenttext: Yes. Our street rate growth for October is slightly lower than where it was in the third quarter. So you are mid-5s in street rate growth, mid- to upper 5s depending on kind of the time. Discounts are pretty similar to what they were in the third quarter, up slightly, but -- the reason we're adjusting discounts and pricing is obviously to try to recoup some of the occupancy that we were down.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So if I look at your guidance, adjusted guidance and what it implies for the fourth quarter, we're roughly looking at like a low 5% same-store revenue growth rate. What's interesting about that is that, probably, that your rent per occupied square
componenttext: Right. So if I look at your guidance, adjusted guidance and what it implies for the fourth quarter, we're roughly looking at like a low 5% same-store revenue growth rate. What's interesting about that is that, probably, that your rent per occupied square foot growth rate for the first time is going to surpass same-store revenue growth rate, at least it's trending that way. So it feels like there may be some levers, whether that's promotions like we talked about or existing customer rate increases having a lower benefit to those same-store revenue numbers or just decrease in street rates. But it feels like there are some other levers that are giving way, so I was wondering if you had any thoughts on that.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you in terms of levers, the majority of our growth at the end of last year and all of this year has been street rate growth. Existing customer rate increases don't add a lot, but it is almost entirely rate growth. That has been offset sl
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you in terms of levers, the majority of our growth at the end of last year and all of this year has been street rate growth. Existing customer rate increases don't add a lot, but it is almost entirely rate growth. That has been offset slightly by discounts, and bad debt has increased nominally also.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess in the same line of questioning, I know we tend to focus a lot on the supply issues, but maybe just something on the demand side because it feels like even your good markets are not just -- not as much as L.A. but just overall, some of t
componenttext: Okay. And I guess in the same line of questioning, I know we tend to focus a lot on the supply issues, but maybe just something on the demand side because it feels like even your good markets are not just -- not as much as L.A. but just overall, some of the great markets are becoming just very good and just kind of toning down a notch. Is there something that you can point to on the demand side? Are customers shopping price more often? Or is there just less traffic? Or are there some things that you're seeing out there that is pointing towards just a little bit weaker demand than what we're used to?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing is just the cyclicality of markets. If you -- we did a study, we looked at almost 90 markets over a 10-year period, and one thing you see is that markets are strong and then markets are less strong and they're not correlated and
componenttext: I think what we're seeing is just the cyclicality of markets. If you -- we did a study, we looked at almost 90 markets over a 10-year period, and one thing you see is that markets are strong and then markets are less strong and they're not correlated and they move in all different directions. Our #1 market for 10-year NOI growth is Chicago, which is now one of our weaker markets. So we fully expect to see markets like Sacramento be very strong for a few years and then perhaps be not as strong. One of our markets now that we reported as a weaker market is Boston. Boston is not a market that's been impacted by a lot of supply, but it's just kind of in that cyclical pattern that we see. So we're very happy to have designed a portfolio that is highly, highly diversified across many, many markets that will smooth out the ups and downs of individual markets.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats, Spencer, on retirement. And congrats, Joe, on your new role. Two quick questions, just on the comments about steady state, can you give us some context? If I look at like the last 10 years, self storage same-store NOI is probably in the 4% to 5%
componenttext: Congrats, Spencer, on retirement. And congrats, Joe, on your new role. Two quick questions, just on the comments about steady state, can you give us some context? If I look at like the last 10 years, self storage same-store NOI is probably in the 4% to 5% same-store NOI range. And I'm just trying to understand like when you say steady state, given sort of all the changes in technology, et cetera, is that somewhere in between the long-term average and today's numbers? Is it -- can you just give us some sense of what steady state means?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you, we're reverting back to that historical average of 4% to 5%. And I think as a company, that's largely our belief. You're going to have times it's above that -- they're not going to be way above. And there's times you're going to be below
componenttext: I would tell you, we're reverting back to that historical average of 4% to 5%. And I think as a company, that's largely our belief. You're going to have times it's above that -- they're not going to be way above. And there's times you're going to be below that and they're not going to be way below. It is the beauty of self storage is that it is a fairly stable property type.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on supply, in talking to several private operators, it seems like in markets where there was this uptick in supply, given the performance, subsequent performance, it seems like some projects are getting either pushed out or delayed, an
componenttext: Okay. And then just on supply, in talking to several private operators, it seems like in markets where there was this uptick in supply, given the performance, subsequent performance, it seems like some projects are getting either pushed out or delayed, and it's also just taking longer to get new projects started just given capacity issues in terms of contractors. I'm just wondering if you've seen that in any markets.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We see that across all markets, that a fairly sizable percentage of planned projects do not get built because of local opposition, increasing construction costs, difficulty getting financing, land costs get too high, whatever it is. But that being said, t
componenttext: We see that across all markets, that a fairly sizable percentage of planned projects do not get built because of local opposition, increasing construction costs, difficulty getting financing, land costs get too high, whatever it is. But that being said, there are projects being added to the funnel, and a good portion of them get -- don't make it through the funnel, but there are still more projects getting added to the funnel. So I think the factors you talked about, it will slow and moderate the development cycle but not stop it.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gaurav Mehta from Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gaurav Mehta from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick ones. Number one, for your existing customers, have you seen any pushback from your tenants on rent increases? And can you comment on percentage of move-outs for rent increases in your portfolio?
componenttext: A couple of quick ones. Number one, for your existing customers, have you seen any pushback from your tenants on rent increases? And can you comment on percentage of move-outs for rent increases in your portfolio?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have not seen any changes, if that's the question. We still have a very small percentage of customers who will actually go get their boxes and move out when they get a rate increase. We continue to -- every time we sent out a rent increase, keep a c
componenttext: So we have not seen any changes, if that's the question. We still have a very small percentage of customers who will actually go get their boxes and move out when they get a rate increase. We continue to -- every time we sent out a rent increase, keep a control group and measure the control group's move-out rate against the folks who got the rate increase; I think about 1% of the people move out. So there's been no change in that, it's something we continue to monitor, and it proves to us that the rate increase program continues to be valuable.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the second, you talked about discounts, higher discounts in the quarter. Were there any markets where you had to use more discounts than others?
componenttext: Okay. And the second, you talked about discounts, higher discounts in the quarter. Were there any markets where you had to use more discounts than others?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any market that's shown softness in terms of occupancy or rate, we will typically increase the discount. As we look at the levers we have to pull, you're going to look first to increase your spend on the web. The last thing you want to do is decrease your
componenttext: Any market that's shown softness in terms of occupancy or rate, we will typically increase the discount. As we look at the levers we have to pull, you're going to look first to increase your spend on the web. The last thing you want to do is decrease your rate. So in terms of magnitude, you'll typically increase your spend on the web, you will increase your discounts or you will change your rate. And you typically want to do them in that order because of the cost -- the long-term cost or benefit.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question from the line of Gwen Clark from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question from the line of Gwen Clark from Evercore ISI.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an update on how you're thinking about valet storage, the threat to the industry and then also some color on, say, clicks per foot?
componenttext: Can you give us an update on how you're thinking about valet storage, the threat to the industry and then also some color on, say, clicks per foot?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've done quite a bit in terms of research on the valet storage, and we don't see it as an imminent threat. We understand it a lot. We've done deliveries with several companies. We have done click-throughs to see if they choose them over us. And rig
componenttext: Yes. We've done quite a bit in terms of research on the valet storage, and we don't see it as an imminent threat. We understand it a lot. We've done deliveries with several companies. We have done click-throughs to see if they choose them over us. And right now, based on the way it's priced, we do not see it as a major threat. The other thing we have is the ability to get into that business fairly quickly. We have the real estate, we have the customer list, so not a huge threat at this time.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Then on a different note, it looks like Denver was one of the first markets to go negative. Can you give us an update on how to think about what markets could be next and what would be driving that?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Then on a different note, it looks like Denver was one of the first markets to go negative. Can you give us an update on how to think about what markets could be next and what would be driving that?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's tough to predict the future. If you looked at a market that has had 15% growth 2 years in a row and had a lot of new supply, I think that it's probable that market is not going to be great next year. And if you like, I think we can discuss that offli
componenttext: It's tough to predict the future. If you looked at a market that has had 15% growth 2 years in a row and had a lot of new supply, I think that it's probable that market is not going to be great next year. And if you like, I think we can discuss that offline here [ph] .

componenttext: Scott, I appreciate the comment on -- in regards to not focusing necessarily on what your share price is today in terms of driving your external growth strategy. But what is it that the team looks for that would -- or that will eventually tell you that it is time to slow growth from that perspective?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you when things are not accretive anymore, so in other words, what you're paying for a property is greater than your cost of capital. So we're very careful in terms of assessing our cost of equity as well as assessing our cost of debt and try
componenttext: I would tell you when things are not accretive anymore, so in other words, what you're paying for a property is greater than your cost of capital. So we're very careful in terms of assessing our cost of equity as well as assessing our cost of debt and try to look at that long term and having realistic growth assumptions. But I think that's what could cause you a bigger problem is if pricing stays extremely low.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then you've obviously seen great success on producing this double-digit FFO growth over many consecutive quarters now. Do you consider that a hard target internally as you're looking at acquisitions? Or is that more just an outcome of what you -- what -- the strategy that you've employed and you're okay with not producing double-digit FFO growth at a certain point in time?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we are not okay with not producing, that's too many negatives, sorry. We -- our goal -- we are very focused on producing double-digit FFO growth, both through acquisitions and all the other levers we have to pull that are -- to do that, whether that's
componenttext: No, we are not okay with not producing, that's too many negatives, sorry. We -- our goal -- we are very focused on producing double-digit FFO growth, both through acquisitions and all the other levers we have to pull that are -- to do that, whether that's, as we talked about, restructuring our ventures, our ManagementPlus platform. We will add over 9,000 units this year through expansions or confabs [ph] where we've turned 10s by 10s to 5s by 5s. So we are very focused on that goal.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: No, they're still high single digits.

componenttext: High single. Okay. And then are you able to quantify what the rolldown is from move out to move in for the quarter?

componenttext: Yes. It depends on what we're doing with street rates, but they're typically low to mid-single digits, and they can get as bad as high single-digits. Right now, you're more in the low to mid with the fact that you've been pushing your street rates.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Stender from Wells Fargo.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to get a sense of how you're evaluating your cost of capital, how you're deploying capital at this point in the cycle. Can you talk about the 3 buckets that you invested in, the JV assets that sound like they're pretty mature. I think you acqu
componenttext: I just want to get a sense of how you're evaluating your cost of capital, how you're deploying capital at this point in the cycle. Can you talk about the 3 buckets that you invested in, the JV assets that sound like they're pretty mature. I think you acquired 3 properties outside of that in the quarter and then your CofO deals. Is there a way to quantify your return expectations side by side with those 3?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of questions all in one, Todd. I think I can tell you we're very focused on the long-term cost of capital. That's going to take into consideration debt as well as equity, and it's going to be the mix of debt and equity. In terms of returns, we are t
componenttext: A lot of questions all in one, Todd. I think I can tell you we're very focused on the long-term cost of capital. That's going to take into consideration debt as well as equity, and it's going to be the mix of debt and equity. In terms of returns, we are typically a cap rate buyer. We also consider your replacement costs. We also look at IRRs, and we also look at cash-on-cash yields. Because we are a long-term holder, I think cash-on-cash is probably the most relevant one that we focus on. Rather than just looking at a cap rate today or stabilized cap rate, what's the return, because that equalizes -- if you look at a 7-year cash-on-cash return on a CofO deal, you now can compare that to how is that cash-on-cash yield do in acquisition? So I would tell you, we're focused on long-term cost of capital, we're focused on cap rates and cash-on-cash yield.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the other thing to add is if you look at those 3 types of acquisitions, they all serve a different purpose, right? The assets we buy from a joint venture partner that we've managed, we have already maximized performance, there's less upside in tho
componenttext: I guess the other thing to add is if you look at those 3 types of acquisitions, they all serve a different purpose, right? The assets we buy from a joint venture partner that we've managed, we have already maximized performance, there's less upside in those assets, but there's also less risk. We know them inside and out, we know exactly what the performance is, there's already branded. So those are kind of our safest, lowest returning assets. The CofO deals where we're taking full lease-up risk -- construction risk, and we have the period of dilution that Scott mentioned, those are higher returning type deals in return for taking that lease-up risk. And then the deals we buy on market, they span the globe. There's deals -- our first-year cap rate on acquired deals range from 2.7% to 8%. So that just tells you how much juice there is or lease-up or value is -- adders in those deals. So those could be anywhere along the spectrum.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what are you guys expecting? What's the cash-on-cash return for the Pru assets because it sounds like we're going to see some more JV assets being pulled into Q4, what kind of return expectations there?
componenttext: So what are you guys expecting? What's the cash-on-cash return for the Pru assets because it sounds like we're going to see some more JV assets being pulled into Q4, what kind of return expectations there?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the deal we just announced with PRISA II where we dissolved that joint venture and purchased 23 assets, the 4.12 cap rate on that was a 5.8. So that gives you a sense of that.
componenttext: So the deal we just announced with PRISA II where we dissolved that joint venture and purchased 23 assets, the 4.12 cap rate on that was a 5.8. So that gives you a sense of that.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's tough to give you the cash-on-cash yields because they vary so much depending on lease-up, CofO versus bp [ph] . I would tell you a JV is more like buying the safe annuity and some of the others are more swinging for the fences, much higher retu
componenttext: Yes, it's tough to give you the cash-on-cash yields because they vary so much depending on lease-up, CofO versus bp [ph] . I would tell you a JV is more like buying the safe annuity and some of the others are more swinging for the fences, much higher returns.

componenttext: So we try to target -- we target 200 basis points over what we believe a stabilized asset -- what we would buy a stabilized asset for in that market. componenttext: So I would tell you, from a property tax perspective, it will be above inflation. I mean, the last couple of years, we've seen 4% to 6%. We expect that again next year. We hope to be able to grow less than inflation in some of the other areas by some of the things we're doing. So hopefully, that will offset some of it. But in terms of marketing, hopefully, as we grow, we will start to experience some of the size and scale benefit. So we hope to keep that somewhere near inflationary also.

And then part two is do you think that helps your valuation in the stock as you guys kind of move towards a more, I'd say, modern-era REIT?

componenttextpreview: I would tell you it does a couple of things for us. One is hopefully it decreases our average cost of debt and then, two, hopefully it extends out the average length of maturity. In terms of whether or not that increases the value, I think that I'll leave
componenttext: I would tell you it does a couple of things for us. One is hopefully it decreases our average cost of debt and then, two, hopefully it extends out the average length of maturity. In terms of whether or not that increases the value, I think that I'll leave that to the investors and the analysts.

componenttext: I think there's some confusion about what normalized growth means for the sector and for Extra Space. Can you try to quantify it a bit more specifically?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so there are a lot of numbers out there. Gwen, it's Spencer. And if you look back over the last 10-plus years, it's hard to get an exact read on this because you got some occupancy gains and other things mixed in there. But some numbers that I've use
componenttext: Yes, so there are a lot of numbers out there. Gwen, it's Spencer. And if you look back over the last 10-plus years, it's hard to get an exact read on this because you got some occupancy gains and other things mixed in there. But some numbers that I've used in the past for the 10-year average for this group, the storage sector, operators specifically, the NOI growth has been about 5.3%. That's a very healthy report card in the world of REITs by any measure. Extra Space has done a little bit better than that. We have averaged about 6.7% over that 10-plus year period. And the last quarter we just reported was 7.8%. We're still way above the historical norm. And you can pull out some of the occupancy and other things that might be inflating some of those numbers, but my personal opinion is, not only today but going forward, storage will be amongst the best, if not the best performing asset class. So yes, we've seen some deceleration. I'm personally a little surprised at the negativity, but I have a high degree of confidence that storage, and Extra Space, in particular, are going to put up excellent results by any measure in the world of REITs. And I don't think any of that changes. So reverting to maybe more normal historical trends, it's still impressive.

componenttext: Okay, so that's helpful. And it seems like there's clearly some benefit from occupancy and then, in more recent years, the TI. Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Extra Space Storage Inc. Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's program is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's program, Jeff Norman, Senior Director of Investor Relations for Extra Space Storage.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website. Please remember that management's prepared remarks and
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website. Please remember that management's prepared remarks and answers to your questions may contain forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act. Actual results could differ materially from those stated or implied by our forward-looking statements due to risks and uncertainties associated with the company's business. These forward-looking statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in the company's latest filings with the SEC, which we encourage our listeners to review.
Forward-looking statements represent management's estimates as of today, Thursday, October 27, 2016. The company assumes no obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements because of changing market conditions or other circumstances after the date of this conference call. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Spencer Kirk, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. As many of you know, last month, I announced that I will be retiring at the end of the year, and that I will be succeeded by our Chief Investment Officer, Joe Margolis. I've had the opportunity to work with Joe for more than 18 years. He
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. As many of you know, last month, I announced that I will be retiring at the end of the year, and that I will be succeeded by our Chief Investment Officer, Joe Margolis. I've had the opportunity to work with Joe for more than 18 years. He was instrumental in structuring our first JV with Prudential in 1998. He served on our Board of Directors for more than a decade, and he has excelled in his role as our Chief Investment Officer. He has the right balance of real estate expertise and leadership skills to lead Extra Space in its continued growth and success. 
So at this time, I'd like to turn the time over to Joe.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Spencer. Good afternoon, everybody. It has been great to meet with many of you face to face since we announced Spencer's retirement, and I look forward to getting to know you better through future interactions. It was another strong quarter f
componenttext:
Thank you, Spencer. Good afternoon, everybody. It has been great to meet with many of you face to face since we announced Spencer's retirement, and I look forward to getting to know you better through future interactions. 
It was another strong quarter for Extra Space. FFO per share as adjusted grew 26% year-over-year. This growth was the result of more than solid operating performance. It was also fueled by accretive acquisitions, joint ventures, third-party management and an optimized balance sheet. We are focused on using all of these levers to continue to grow shareholder value. 
Operationally, we continue to push rates to new and existing customers in the quarter and experienced average street rate of growth of approximately 7%, similar to 2015. This growth was partially offset by an increase in bad debt and discounts, which resulted in same-store revenue growth of 6.1%. 
Discounts, while still very low from an historical measure, are up from an all-time low in 2015. Expenses increased only 1.4%, which led to NOI growth of 7.8%. Quarter-end occupancy was strong at 93%. 
Year-to-date, we have acquired $825 million in wholly-owned stores. With very few exceptions, these acquisitions were not broadly marketed but came from our JV, managed and other relationships. The largest of the off-market transactions closed on September 16, when we purchased Prudential's majority interest in 23 stores for $238 million. 
Concurrently, we sold our minority interest to Prudential in the remaining 42 stores in the joint venture for $35 million. We will continue to manage these stores. 
In addition, we are under agreement with a JV partner to purchase its majority interest in 11 stores for approximately $153 million. We plan to close this transaction in the fourth quarter, which will result in wholly-owned acquisitions of $1 billion in 2016.
We also expect to close $255 million in CofO acquisitions in 2016. $90 million of these will be wholly owned and the remainder will be in joint ventures, with our investment in these ventures totaling $53 million. Our JV strategy and our CofO program are working and are creating value year in and year out. 
I would now like to turn the time over to Scott.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $1.02 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by $0.02. Including costs associated with acquisitions and noncash interest expense, FFO was $1 per share for the quarter. The beat was primari
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $1.02 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by $0.02. Including costs associated with acquisitions and noncash interest expense, FFO was $1 per share for the quarter. The beat was primarily the result of stronger-than-anticipated performance from our 2015 acquisitions, specifically SmartStop. We also benefited from the collection of $1 million in business interruption insurance proceeds. 
As Joe mentioned, our same-store revenue growth was driven by higher rates to new and existing customers. This is consistent with our guidance, which assume no benefit from occupancy and a headwind from discounts in the second half of 2016. We continue to have solid revenue and NOI growth throughout our diversified portfolio.
Our top-performing markets in the quarter included Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Sacramento, San Diego and Tampa/St. Pete, with revenue growth in the high single-digits. The slowest markets were Boston, Chicago, Denver, Houston and Memphis. With the exception of Denver, which represents about 1% of our revenue, all of our markets showed positive revenue growth year-over-year.
Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we completed a $1.15 billion unsecured credit facility. The facility consists of a $500 million revolving line of credit; a 5-year, $430 million term loan; and a 7-year, $220 million term loan. The credit facility has an accordion feature that allows us to increase total capacity to $1.5 billion. 
At closing, we drew $300 million on a 5-year tranche and paid off and terminated 3 of our 4 bilateral revolving lines of credit. The 5- and 7-year tranches have delayed draw features. We will access the remaining available term balances as needed to finance future acquisitions and to pay off debt.
This unsecured facility further diversifies our capital structure and reduces our average interest rate. Our goal is to have access to multiple types of capital to ladder maturities and to maintain financial stability. This credit facility helps accomplish all of these goals.
Due to the outperformance of our 2015 acquisitions, we are increasing our annual FFO guidance. FFO as adjusted is now estimated to be $3.78 to $3.80 per share. FFO is now estimated to be $3.63 to $3.65 per share. This guidance includes $0.05 of dilution from our 2015 and 2016 CofO stores. It also includes acquisitions that, as anticipated, will require time to be brought up to our performance standards. As these properties move towards our portfolio average, we expect outsized NOI growth. 
I will now turn the time back to Spencer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. This is my final earnings call as the CEO of Extra Space. I've enjoyed working with each of you, and I am grateful for the relationships and friendships that have been developed over the years. Going forward, I will continue to be activel
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. This is my final earnings call as the CEO of Extra Space. I've enjoyed working with each of you, and I am grateful for the relationships and friendships that have been developed over the years. 
Going forward, I will continue to be actively involved as a member of the board, and I will remain the company's largest individual shareholder. My interests are perfectly aligned with those of our shareholders. 
Thinking back 7.5 years ago when I took over as CEO, it wasn't about my predecessor, Ken Woolley, and today, it isn't about Spencer Kirk. It's always been about our competent and capable executive team, which has an average tenure of 14 years. I am 100% comfortable that Joe Margolis is the right person at the right time to lead this very strong team. Our unique structure and our ability to execute a clear business strategy has allowed us to be among the fastest-growing REITs in the nation. None of that changes with this transition. 
Over the last 5 years, we have profitably acquired over $5 billion of real estate. These acquisitions alone would constitute one of the largest storage companies in the nation. When you combine that kind of external growth with the industry's best operating platform, which just delivered its 24th consecutive quarter of double-digit FFO growth, Extra Space is well positioned to continue to deliver outsized growth for years to come. 
With that, let's turn it over to Jeff to start the Q&A.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Spencer. [Operator Instructions] With that, we'll turn it over to Jonathan to start our Q&A.
componenttext: Thank you, Spencer. [Operator Instructions] With that, we'll turn it over to Jonathan to start our Q&A.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I had a question in terms of the acquisitions and sort of plans for long-term funding. Obviously, a lot more acquisitions this quarter and for the year -- more than planned. But given where the stock price is trading, curious what your plans are fo
componenttext: Scott, I had a question in terms of the acquisitions and sort of plans for long-term funding. Obviously, a lot more acquisitions this quarter and for the year -- more than planned. But given where the stock price is trading, curious what your plans are for funding those acquisitions and if you'd be comfortable raising equity at the current price.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, I would tell you that we don't look at our current stock price anytime we make an acquisition decision. It's not made with a short-term cost of capital in mind. We always look at the long-term cost. So we've always tried to have many so
componenttext: Yes, first of all, I would tell you that we don't look at our current stock price anytime we make an acquisition decision. It's not made with a short-term cost of capital in mind. We always look at the long-term cost. So we've always tried to have many sources of capital. And right now, I would tell you that we still do. Debt is an option. We just closed this facility and it gives us a fair amount of capacity. The preferred market's still very good. And our stock price, we don't like it as much today as we have in the past, but I think that we'll always look to access the cheapest cost of capital which could also include joint ventures or even proceeds from the sales of properties.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So would you be willing to increase debt levels for the short term until maybe you have a better stock price?
componenttext: So would you be willing to increase debt levels for the short term until maybe you have a better stock price?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marginally, yes, we would.
componenttext: Marginally, yes, we would.
